loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Lucila vive con su esposo y sus 5 hijos en su casa propia. Desde muy joven se ha dedicado a la agricultura, ella siembra alfalfa, cría ganado ovino y animales menores (gallinas), en un lugar que implementó en su vivienda. Su esposo la ayuda en estas tareas, pero también él trabaja independiente. 
Lucila distribuye su tiempo tanto para el cuidado de sus animales, como para atender su hogar y a sus hijos. Pero durante los fines de semana es cuando vende sus animales y compra otros para hacerlos crecer y engordar. El deseo a futuro de Lucila es tener una granja de animales grandes para poder incrementar sus ganancias.

Esta es la quinta oportunidad en que tiene un crédito con MFP y está muy contenta de ser parte de su banco comunal, pues le ha traído muchas satisfacciones. El dinero que ahora solicita lo invertirá en la compra de más animales, especialmente ovejas.
texts.en:
Lucila lives in her own home with her husband and their 5 children. She has been farming from a very young age. Lucila grows alfalfa and breeds sheep and chickens in a designated area outside of her home. Her husband helps her with these tasks, but he also works independently.

Lucila divides her time among caring for her animals, tending to the housework, and looking after her children. On the weekends, she sells her animals and buys others for breeding and fattening. In the future, she would like to have a farm with larger animals so that she can increase her earnings.

This is the fifth time Lucila has taken a loan with MFP. She is thrilled to be part of her Communal Bank since it has brought her much satisfaction. The money she is requesting will be used to buy more animals, especially sheep.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sheep

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María tiene 38 años, vive con su esposo  y sus 3 hijos en su casa propia. Desde hace 5 años se dedica la crianza de animales (vacas), para ello implementó un espacio adecuado en su terreno donde construyó un establo para protegerlos de las lluvias. Todas las mañanas, María lleva a sus vacas a pastar en campos verdes, pero aun así no descuida la atención de sus hijos, pues sigue muy pendiente de sus necesidades y labores escolares. 
Para estas labores, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo para transportar a sus vacas a los pastizales donde se alimentarán. 
El deseo a futuro de María es tener un establo más grande y mejor implementado para la crianza de mayor cantidad de animales. 

Esta es la sexta oportunidad en que tiene un crédito con MFP, ella es una socia responsable y perseverante dentro de su banco comunal, lo cual es apreciado por sus demás compañeros. El dinero que ahora solicita lo utilizará en la compra de dos vacas pequeñas de buena raza.
texts.en:
María is 38 years old and lives in her own home with her husband and their 3 children. For the past 5 years, she has been breeding cattle on an adequate space of land containing a barn that was constructed to protect them from the rain. Every morning, she brings her cows out to graze in the green fields. María still looks after her children because she is very aware of their needs and their schoolwork. Her husband provides assistance by transporting the animals to pasture whenever they need to feed. In the future, María would like to have a bigger barn so that she can breed more animals.

This is her sixth loan with MFP. María is a responsible member who has persevered with her Communal Bank. The other members have much appreciation for her. The money she is requesting will be used to buy two small cows of good breed.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase two cows

loans.name: Marilu

texts.es:
Marilu tiene 44 años, vive con su esposo y sus hijos en su casa propia. Desde hace 3 años tiene una granja de cuyes y pollos, y para su cuidado distribuye adecuadamente su tiempo, ya que también trabaja en la municipalidad de su localidad. 
Marilu alimenta, diariamente por las mañanas, a sus animales y regresa a medio día para darles una segunda ración. Durante los fines de semana se dedica a seleccionar a sus animales para venderlos en la feria de su localidad, como así también algunos clientes viene a su misma casa para comprar sus animales. 
La otra opción de ventas que ha estado analizando Marilu es abastecer a las personas que elaboran banquetes donde preparan comidas a base de cuy o pollo, para lo cual empezará a buscar los contactos necesarios. Para la atención de granja cuenta con la ayuda de su esposo e hijos y su gran anhelo es tener un lugar con todos los estándares de calidad para la crianza de sus animales.

Esta es la quinta oportunidad en que tiene un crédito con MFP y está muy contenta de ser parte de un banco comuna, por lo que se compromete nuevamente a ser puntual en sus pagos. El dinero que ahora solicita lo utilizará en la compra de madera y mallas metálicas para la construcción de galpones para su granja. También adquirirá más cuyes reproductores.
texts.en:
Marilu is 44 years old and lives in her own home with her husband and children. For the past 3 years, she has been breeding guinea pigs and chickens. Marilu also has a job with the local municipality.

Every morning, Marilu feeds her animals and then returns at noon to give them their second ration. On the weekends, she selects the animals to sell at the local fair. In addition, she has a few customers who come to her house to buy their animals. Another option Marilu is considering is to sell to people who prepare banquets in which guinea pigs and chickens are served. She has already started looking for contacts in this area. Marilu has the help of her husband and children to look after her animals. Her greatest desire is to have a place that meets the quality standards necessary for breeding animals.

Marilu is taking her fifth loan with MFP. She is thrilled to be a member of her Communal Bank and renews her promise to make her payments on time. The money she is requesting will be used to purchase wood and metal fencing in order to build a shed to house her animals. She also would like to acquire more fertile guinea pigs for breeding.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a shed to house her animals

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
Maruja tiene 47 años, vive con su esposo y sus hijos en su casa propia. Desde hace 20 años se dedica al bordado de fustanes (faldas) artesanales, los cuales realiza con  mucha dedicación y empeño para dejar satisfechos a sus clientes. Esta labor, Maruja la hace en la comodidad de su casa y en ocasiones con la ayuda de una de sus hijas, que es cuando avanza mucho más rápido. Pero dependiendo de la complejidad del bordado puede demorar  hasta un mes.
Lo que le agrada a Maruja de estos bordados es el buen precio que le pagan por su trabajo y eso la motiva a continuar. Para el futuro, ella desea renovar sus herramientas para adquirir mayor velocidad en su producción.

Es la sétima oportunidad que tiene un crédito en MFP, es una de las socias de mayor trayectoria en su banco comunal. El dinero que ahora solicita lo invertirá en la compra de los materiales para bordar, tales como: hilos, telas y un bastidor. Por otro lado, Maruja también invertirá en un nuevo negocio, que es la venta de leña, para lo cual comprará madera en grandes cantidades.
texts.en:
Maruja is 47 years old and lives in her own home with her husband and their children. For 20 years, she has been making embroidered skirts and continues to do so with great dedication and commitment so that her customers remain happy. Maruja performs her work in the comfort of her home and sometimes with the help of one of her daughters, which helps speed up the process. However, depending on the complexity of the design, some embroideries can take a month to complete.

Maruja is pleased that her embroideries command a good price because it reflects the quality of her work and motivates her to continue. In the future, she would like to replace her tools so that she can complete more pieces at a faster rate of production.

Maruja is receiving her seventh loan with MFP. She is one of the long-standing members of her Communal Bank. The money she requested will be used to purchase embroidery materials such as thread, cloth, and a sewing frame. In addition, Maruja would like to start a new business selling firewood, so part of the proceeds will be used to buy timber in large quantities.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase embroidery materials & invest in a new business

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es: El señor Jose  se dedica a la fabricacion de juguetes, almohadas y mochilas desde hace 4 años. Tiene su taller en la Av. principal de la zona de Villa San Antonio. Él y su esposa, la señora Remedios, viven en la misma avenida pero a dos casas del taller,en la casa de su suegra. Tienen una pequeña hija de cuatro años de edad. Jose Luis es una persona muy hábil y trabajadora ya que tiene un taller con varias máquinas y ayudantes  y vela siempre por el bienestar de su familia
texts.en:
Sr. Jose Luis has been manufacturing toys, pillows, and backpacks for four years. He has a workshop on the main avenue in the district of Villa San Antonio. He and his wife, Sra. Remedios, live on the same street but two buildings down from the workshop at his mother-in-law’s house. They have a young daughter who is 4 years old. Jose Luis is very skilled at his job and a hard worker. His workshop is equipped with several machines and staffed with assistants, which enables him to provide for his family’s welfare.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bright fabrics, thread, and black wool

loans.name: Eleuteria

texts.en:
Eleuteria B. is from the village of Talic. She is 50 years old, married, and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Eleuteria owns & operates a hog fattening business. Eleuteria has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Eleuteria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eleuteria has successfully repaid one previous loan from PMPC. Eleuteria is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase piglets to raise & sell in future.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda tiene 50 años, vive con sus 2 hijos en su casa propia. Desde hace 2 años cría ganado vacuno, por lo que todos los días atiende a sus animales en el establo que implementó en el terreno donde está su vivienda. Yolanda sale por las mañanas a cortar los pastos que sirven de alimento para sus vacas y en esto tiene sumo cuidado, pues la alimentación es la base para que estén saludables y los pueda ofertar a un mejor precio. Por ello, Yolanda quiere mejorar la infraestructura de su establo, además de asistir a una capacitación donde le enseñen las mejores técnicas de crianza. 

Esta es la quinta oportunidad  en que tiene un préstamo con MFP, ella es muy responsable y puntual en el pago de sus cuotas, lo cual promueve en sus compañeros de banco comunal. El dinero que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de una vaca de mejor raza.
texts.en:
Yolanda is 50 years old and lives in her own home with her 2 children. She has been breeding cattle for the past 2 years. Every day she attends to her animals in the stable that was built on her property. Yolanda comes out in the mornings to cut grasses to feed to her cows. She is careful in managing their diet since food is the basis for keeping them healthy and attracting better prices at market. Yolanda would like to make improvements to her stable as well as attend a training class to learn better breeding techniques.

This is the fifth time she has received a loan from MFP. Yolanda is very responsible and punctual with her payments, which is highly encouraged by the other Communal Bank members. The money she is requesting will be used to buy a cow of good breed.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a cow

loans.name: Nelson Cecilio

texts.es: Don Nelson tiene su tienda donde ofrece el servicio de internet, y tiene también su cabina telefónica pública, es una persona muy responsable, con sólo 26 años de edad ya tiene su negocio bien establecido, el cual fue creciendo poco a poco, su hermana mayor es quien le apoya en sus proyectos y le impulsa a terminar sus estudios en la universidad, vive en la casa de sus padres donde también colabora con los gastos de la casa. Es un cliente antiguo de la institución y el crédito que solicita es para la compra de accesorios para computadora para mejorar el servicio al cliente.
texts.en:
Don Nelson has a shop where he offers Internet service and a public phone booth. For being only 26 years old, he is a responsible person and already has an established business that has been steadily growing. His older sister helps him with his endeavors and encourages him to finish his college education. Nelson lives at home with his parents and contributes toward the household expenses. He is a long-time client of the Institution and is requesting a loan to buy computer accessories so that he can provide better service to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase computer accessories

loans.name: Nening

texts.en: Nening D. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 21 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Nening owns and operates a small variety store, selling a variety of daily-use products and foods in the local community. She has improved her business activity as the years have passed by and as her loan amounts have increased. In 2008, Nening joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Nening is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Julie

texts.en: Julie D. is from the village of Tugas, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Julie owns a specialized retail store, selling a variety of products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Julie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Julie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for house renovation. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use for house renovation

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
At 52 years old, Amelia is already a widow. She has four children who are all married. At present she is living at Barangay Alinam, Cauayan City, Isabela, together with her daughter and grandchildren.

Amelia has been engaged in fruit and vegetable vending in their small village for almost twenty-eight years. Her weekly net income is Php 2,000 which she utilizes for their daily needs, especially for their daily food.

Wanting to buy additional vegetables and fruit for her vending business Amelia wants to apply for a loan of Php 14,000 from Kiva lenders for the additional requirements of her business. She wants to support her family in their daily needs, especially the financial aspect, so that they will have better living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: Edna N. and her family live in Salitran, Dasmarinas, Cavite, in the southern part of Metro Manila. Edna is 57 years old. Her husband, Hospicio, is a government employee and they have three children, the youngest being in college. Edna owns and manages a bakery and a small grocery store. She opened it three years ago with only an assistant working at the oven. Now, her bakery employs six bakers rotating as store attendants and delivery personnel as well. She earns at least P26,000 a month. Edna has just finished repaying her previous loan with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative so she applied for a new loan of P15,000 to purchase more bakery supplies such as flour, sugar and lard. This is her 4th loan with the cooperative. Edna wishes enroll in a baking school so she is able to learn more of the fundamentals of the bakery business. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more bakery supplies

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en: Mrs. Sophea N. lives in Pour Village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land, on which she cultivates rice. She now faces a small problem with insects that destroy the rice crop. To deal with this, Mrs. Sophea N. is asking for a loan. With the money, she will buy more pesticides to kill all kinds of insects. Her husband, Mr. Doek Sopha, helps her farm. Mrs. Sophea N. has three children, all of whom are attending the local school.

loans.use: purchasing more pesticides to kill all types of insects

loans.name: Mrs. Roatha Pom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank consists of thirteen people and is located in Trapeang SD. village in Takeo province. The members of the group will use the loan in different ways. 

Mrs. Roatha P. was selected to be the village bank president by the group members. She is a silk weaver in the village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it; consequently, she decided to ask for a loan that she will use to buy more silk to weave for her customers. Her husband, Mr. Yaem Chan Lon, helps her run the business. Mrs. Roatha P. has two children, one of whom is attending the local school, and the other of whom is only a one year old.

loans.use: purchasing more silk

loans.name: Mrs. Ngoeurn Suong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people who live in Trapeang Sdok village in Takeo province make up the village bank loan group, and they will use the loan which they obtain for different purposes. 

Mrs. Ngoeurn S. has been selected by the members as village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Lang Neang, owns a small repair shop where he fixes bicycles and motorbikes for an income. Although they work hard, they still earn too little income to support their family. In order to improve the living conditions, Mrs. Ngoeurn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a taxi to transport goods and passengers for an income. Mrs. Ngoeurn S. has a child who is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy a taxi to transport goods and passengers for an income.

loans.name: Mrs. Koem Horn Ngoy Group

texts.en: Mrs. Koem Horn N. is a group leader who lives in Chrouy village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder in the local village. In this business, she now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy pig food; thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy pig food. She is a single woman who lives with her mother.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Ana Cruz

texts.es: Ana Cruz V. D. M. D. 49 años D. edad resiD. en San Pedro Mazahuat en el departamento D. La Paz junto a su esposo y sus hijos. Ana es muy conocida por sus vecinos por ser una persona amable y responsable actualmente tiene una tortillería en su casa con catorce años D. experiencia , también maneja un pequeño inventario en productos D. consumo diario los cuales coloca en una mesa en el terreno D. su casa, el deseo D. Ana es poder consolidar y hacer un negocio formal, instalando una tienda en su casa surtida D. variedad D. productos para el hogar, es por ello que solicita D. un crédito que le permita hacer crecer su negocio que con mucho entusiasmo esta emprendiendo.
texts.en:
Ana Cruz V. D. M. is 49 years old and lives in San Pedro Mazahuat in the department of La Paz with her husband and children. She is well known among her neighbors as a kind and responsible person. Ana has been making tortillas out of her home for 14 years. She also manages a small inventory of everyday consumer products which are displayed on a table outsiD. of her house. Ana would like to turn this into a formal business and establish a store in her home that is stocked with a variety of household products. Therefore she is requesting a loan to grow the business that she has enthusiastically undertaken.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more inventory for her business

loans.name: María

texts.es: María H. reside en el departamento de La Libertad junto a su esposo y, tres hijos y una nieta llamada Esmeralda de 4 años de edad. A pesar que los hijos de María son mayores de edad, ella los sigue apoyando en sus estudios. Don Valentín esposo de María tiene 62 años de edad y se dedica a la venta de pan y María por su parte tiene un negocio ubicado en el mercado donde vende variedad de verduras y frutas por el cual ahora solicita de este crédito, ya que quiere surtir su negocio para la época de noviembre y diciembre por que sus ventas aumentan.
texts.en:
María H. lives in the department of La Libertad with her husband, their three children, and a granddaughter named Esmeralda who is 4 years old. Even though her children are adults, María continues to support their education. Her husband, Don Valentín, is 62 years old and sells bread. In turn, María has a business located in the market where sells a variety of vegetables and fruits.

She is now requesting a loan so that she can restock her business for the months of November and December and increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock her business

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es: Daniel R. O.  de 34 años de edad vive en el departamento de La Libertad junto a su esposa y tres hijos de 16,13 y 4 años.  La esposa de Daniel trabaja de manera ambulante como comerciante para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar, y Daniel por su parte tiene un negocio hace tres años en el mercado central es una venta de frutas y verduras, donde Daniel ofrece productos de excelente calidad y buenos precios, ahora el solicita de un crédito para comprar mayor cantidad de sus productos.
texts.en:
Daniel R. O. is 34 years old and lives in the department of La Libertad with his wife and their 3 children (ages 16, 13, and 4). Daniel’s wife works as a traveling merchant and helps with the household expenses. In turn, Daniel has a business in the central market selling fruits and vegetables. He has been in business for 3 years and offers high-quality products at good prices. The loan he is currently requesting will be used to by a large quantity of products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock his business

loans.name: María De Los Ángeles

texts.es: María De Los Ángeles M. C. reside en la capital de El Salvador. María tiene 32 años de edad vive con su esposo en casa propia. María y su esposo han esperado mucho tiempo para poder tener sus hijos ya que para ellos es importante estabilizarse económicamente y así poder tener el mejor ambiente y disfrutar de sus hijos, por ahora María y su esposo trabajan, él es empleado y María ha montado un negocio hace sietes años, es una tienda de productos de consumo para el hogar y otros artículos como ropa, carteras y zapatos, María proyecta que por medio de este crédito surtirá su tienda con variedad de ropa, la cual ha tenido gran aceptación y demanda por sus clientes.
texts.en:
María De Los Ángeles M. C. lives in San Salvador. She is 32 years old and lives with her husband in their own home. They have waited a long time to start a family because it was important for them to be financially stable and provide a suitable atmosphere in which their children could grow. Both of them work. He is employed, while María manages a business she started seven years ago. She sells consumer products for the home and other items such as clothing, handbags, and shoes.

María will use her loan to increase the variety of clothing in her store, which has gained great acceptance and experienced high demand from her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more inventory

loans.name: Pepetua

texts.en:
Pepetua T. is a 31-year-old woman living in the town of Vaitele K Fou.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To make a living, Pepetua owns & operates a taxi business.  Pepetua has just started operating this business and earns approximately 600ST WST a month from these activities.

Pepetua joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Pepetua is now requesting a new loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service.  Pepetua plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family.

About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and maintain taxi

loans.name: Lakisa

texts.en: M. Lakisa is forty years old, has a family of five and owns a shop selling clothes specifically men's trousers, ties, shirts, t-shirts, belts, etc. The shop is located at Kasese main market in Kasese Town. She operates her business in a rental house but hopes to own her permanent shop some day. Lakisa dreams of developing her retail shop into a wholesale business but has little funds at present. She is requesting this loan to add capital into her business and purchase more supplies of men's clothes so that she can increase her profits and achieve her dream in near future.

loans.use: To add capital into her business and purchase more supplies of men's clothing, for example trousers, ties, shirts, t-shirts, belts, etc

loans.name: Hadijah

texts.en: K. Hadijah is forty-six years old, with a family of four and owns a shop selling clothing. The shop is located in Kasese's main market in Kasese town. She is renting a lock-up for her business and she wishes to construct her own shop some day. K. Hadijah dreams of raising the standards of her shop and her life in the near future if given a chance. By adding capital to her business, she wants to be able to increase and expand her sales. She is requesting a loan to purchase more clothing, both new and used for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing both new and used for resale

loans.name: Sefululima

texts.en:
Sefululima L. is a 68-year-old woman living in the town of Laulii Maagila. She is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Sefululima owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling fried foods in the local community. Sefululima has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 300 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Sefululima joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sefululima is requesting a loan from SPBD for the first time. Sefululima is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Sefululima plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia P. is from the village of Beverly Hills Suarez , Iligan City. She is 57 years old. Alicia is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Alicia owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling ready-to-wear items (RTW) in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alicia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Alicia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mawimbi Group

texts.en:
Nassor R., age 39, is married with three children who are 16, 14, and 11. All three of his children are in school. Nassor owns a charcoal business that he opened earlier this year. The business operates from 7 am until 8 pm every day. Currently, his business makes a profit of about US$ 20 a day, which he uses to pay school fees for his children.

This will be Nassor's first loan from Tujijenge. With the money, he will buy more charcoal to increase his stocks. He will sell this charcoal from his home to both retail and wholesale customers.

Nassor will share this loan with the members of his group, Mawimbi, which means "clouds" in Kiswahili. Most of the sixteen group members are food vendors; one is a fisherman, one sells juice, and another sells soap. They will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans, and meet once a week to make repayments, discuss their businesses, and share advice. In the picture, Nassor is second from the left (crouching down).

loans.use: Charcoal to increase stock of business

loans.name: Pascal

texts.en: M. Pascal, aged thirty-five years old, has a family of six members, that is, four children, his wife, and himself. He is operating a retail/wholesale shop located at Tawakan stores in Kasese Town. He has been in his business so far for five years. He is requesting the loan to purchase retail items such as soap, basins, plates, cooking oil, etc for more profit return. He dreams of developing his shop and he wishes to try his level best to work hard for his business expansion.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as soap, basins, plates, cooking oil, etc

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kisiwani Group

texts.en:
Garlos R. is 23 years old, married, and has two daughters. They are 7 and 3 years old, and their names are Veronica and Queenie. Both of them are in school. Garlos has a "duka" ("shop" in Kiswahili) where he sells items like oil, sodas, and water. The shop is open every day from 7 am to 3 pm. He manages to make a monthly profit of between $80-150. 

Garlos started the business in 2004, but this is his first loan. He will use the loan to buy more stock for his shop and make his business grow. He hopes to put any extra profits back into the business.

Garlos will share this loan with the members of his group, Kisiwani. The sixteen group members run a variety of small businesses, from clothes shops, to vegetable and fruit "table top" stands, to carpentry businesses. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans, meeting once a week to make repayments and discuss their businesses. In the picture, Garlos is third from the left wearing a white shirt and looking over his shoulder.

loans.use: To buy more stock in order to expand business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: M. Joseph is a hard-working businessman and a permanent resident of Kyankuta Kirongo ward. He runs a timber business at Kaguta Road, Kyenjojo town council. He is a single father of seven children; his wife died five years back. He wishes to purchase more timber to expand his business. Timber is in high demand, so he wishes to increase his stock so as to meet the demand of his customers. His dream is to see all his children through school and see them having a great future.

loans.use: To purchase more timber to expand his business.

loans.name: Sera

texts.en:
Sera T. is a 42-year-old woman living in the town of Saanapu 3.  She is married and has 5 children.  To make a living, Sera owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting bananas for sale.  Sera has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 450 WST a month from these activities.

Sera joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Sera has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,250 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  Sera is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  This will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Sera plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie C. is 45 years old. She manages a manicure and pedicure business in her village. She is also a beautician in the village and sometimes she goes to other villages to earn a bigger income for her family needs. Though her business is quite difficult, still she is doing her part as a breadwinner for the family. In her daily routine, she is able to earn PHP 350.

The income she generates from her business is not enough due to a large household size. In this regard, she would like to apply for a loan amounting to PHP 8000. She hopes that she will be granted the loan amount she is requesting.

Tessie has been blessed with three children: Daisy Belshane-20 years old; Yorelle Queen-17 years old; and Nicole-6 years old, who is an elementary pupil. She hopes that she will be able to continue to support her three children.

loans.use: additional capital for business development

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
T. Beatrice is an ambitious entrepreneur with a food store. Her shop is located along Bundibugyo Road in Kisenyi (Rwengoma A2 Zone). She started with little capital in 2007, that is, a few bags of maize and cassava. As the business went on, slowly, she took the maize and cassava for grilling and the stock increased with maize flour and cassava flour. Further, she added millet flour due to the fact that it is jointly demanded with cassava flour as a mixture for a meal.

Beatrice is requesting the loan to add inventory and include beans in her business since people love them as a sauce for meals. And more so in the rainy season, the prices tend to increase which may affect her profits, so she wants to stock up in advance, that is, purchase maize, millet, cassava, and beans in large quantity for her business expansion. Her dream is to see her business be successful.

loans.use: To purchase maize, millet, cassava, and beans in volume

loans.name: Tuafale

texts.en:
Tuafale M. is a 38-year-old woman living in the town of Laulii Maagila. She is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Tuafale owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling baked goods in the local community. Tuafale just begun this business and earns approximately 300 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Tuafale joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tuafale is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Tuafale plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
S. Stephen is an established man with an up-and-coming business. His business is with a variety of clothes: ladies’ suits, bags, dresses, children’s wear, men’s wear - shirts, t-shirts, trousers, jeans, belts, and so forth. His business is located in Mpanga market and he has stayed in his business for five years.

Due to the high demand for clothes in this festive season, Stephen wishes to stock twice a week. He is requesting the loan to purchase more clothes. His dream is to develop his business and be able to supply to others at a wholesale price.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

Cresencia owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years. In 2009, Cresencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Cresencia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
With her desire to earn more income for the welfare of her family, especially her children, Florence M. is really doing her best managing her mini-restaurant located at Magsaysay Saguday, Quirino. Aside from the mini-restaurant, she also sells some merchandise for an extra income.

Already a widow at the age of 51, Florence strives to earn a higher income to support her daily needs and to give some money to her three children, who already have their own families. Florence said that at her age, she still wants to take care and serve her children. For that reason, she wants her business to further progress; thus, she is requesting a loan from ASKI amounting to 7,000 Philippine pesos. She knows that the amount will be of great help to her business.

loans.use: Additional capital for mini-restaurant business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ndejje A Ntege Dorothy Group

texts.en:
N. Dorothy is a married businesswoman, forty years old, and blessed with six children who are schooling. She also has three dependents of whom two are schooling.

Dorothy has a business dealing in bricks and scrap which she has been operating for over six years. She is using the loan for bricklaying and purchasing scrap for recycling in order to expand her business.

Dorothy is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To use for bricklaying and to purchase more scraps for recycling

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Eden is 34 years old, and she is married to Dennis F. who is a lawyer. They have been blessed with a loving son, John Mark, three years old. Her family is happily living in their village. Eden is managing a general merchandise store at the public market of Magsaysay Saguday Quirino. She is thankful because her business is improving but still she would like to expand and offer more of the merchandise she sells. She manage it for the future welfare of their only son.

Eden would like to buy additional merchandise but her capital is not enough and that’s the reason why she would like to take out a loan amounting to PHP 25,000 she would be thankful if her request for a loan is granted.

Eden said that through her “sacrifices and perseverance” she is able to improve her business.

loans.use: additional capital to buy more merchandise for her store

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is a very industrious woman who never stops making profit. She is married to Mario, the one who discovered their product. The couple is blessed with two children; Normar and Marc, both of them are still studying. The couple lives in the peaceful village of Bliss, Ilagan, Isabela.

Norma, along with her husband, has been manufacturing 'foliar' fertilizers for seven years already. Their business is expanding rapidly not only in Isabela province, but nationwide. Norma is seeking assistance from lenders to meet the demands of their customers who need their product. She hopes to access a loan of PHP 30,000 to be used as additional capital in purchasing different ingredients of her 'foliar' fertilizer. This amount will be of big help in expanding her business. She hopes that her loan will be granted.

loans.use: additional capital to buy ingredients for manufacturing

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is already 37 years old. She is married to Victor who works as a soldier. They have three loving children, namely, Mark Anthony, 18 years of age, college level; then Karen Joy, 15 years of age, a fourth year high school student; and Kevin Mark, 9 years of age, a grade 3 student. The family is presently residing at Alinam, Cauayan City, Isabela. Their house is located near Alinam Elementary School.

Marilou has been engaged in retail vending for almost two years; her weekly net income is Php 1,000. She desires to a apply for the loan amount of Php17,000 for additional working capital and for business expansion.She wants to buy additional commodities for her store to acquire more customers. She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her loan request.

loans.use: additional capital for her retail store

She is using the loan to purchase bags of charcoal, firewood, and for laying bricks to improve her businesses. She is a hard-working businesswoman whose dream is to construct a house for the well-being of her family.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal, firewood, and for laying bricks

loans.name: Sulaimon

texts.ru: Шодиев Сулаймон проживаетв в Яванском районе. Возраст 37 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Сулаймон имеет среднее образование. texts.en:
Sulaimon S. lives in the Yavan district. He is 37 years old, married and has 5 children. Sulaimon has secondary education. He has been involved in animal husbandry, raising and selling livestock, for over 5 years. This type of business is his secondary source of income. Besides this, he is involved in passenger transportation; he provides taxi service. He is requesting a loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty owns a retail shop selling day-to-day essentials. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like boxes of soap, cartons of salt, sacks of sugar, and jerry cans of cooking oil. On average, she serves 20 customers a day. Her challenges include defaulters and the rainy season, because, when it rains, very few customers come to her retail shop which is in a muddy place on the outskirts of Kampala. She pays for transport costs to and from her suppliers in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala.

Betty is a 46-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of 13 and 22 years. All her children go to school. She owns a five-room house where she lives with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

Betty has been in her business for six years and with MCDT for ten years, now on her 17th loan working with the same group mates. Betty hopes to see her business grow stronger and wants to start selling only wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise like sacks of sugar, soap and boxes of salt

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma A.'s main source of income comes from making and selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in her community. She is 46 years old, married and has six school-age children. They are from the village of Pandan, Gingoog City. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10,000 pesos a month.

In 2009, Wilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 pesos from HSPFI. This previous loan was used for her carenderia, or eatery business. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 pesos which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Kalala

texts.en:
Kalala F. owns and operates a handicraft business selling plastic handicrafts to tourists and local community members. She is a 33-year-old woman living in the town of Faleasiu Tualesolo. Kalala was not affected by the tsunami which hit Samoa on 9/29/09. She is married and has four school-age children. Kalala has been in her business for less than a year and earns approximately 400 tala a month.

In 2009, Kalala joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Kalala is requesting a loan of 1000 tala which will be used to purchase materials to make additional handicrafts. This will be her first loan from SPBD. Kalala plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make handicrafts

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is married to Ruben and they are blessed with four children. She and her husband successfully send their children to school and two are already college graduates with the assistance of the vegetable-vending business.

Virginia and her husband plant vegetables and, after harvesting them, they sell them wholesale in the market. The income from their business is carefully budgeted to meet the needs of their family and to pay the school fees of their children. Virginia dreams that her two younger children will finish their studies. She and her husband are doing their best for the welfare of their children.

Virginia wants to borrow PHP 10,000 from Kiva lenders for the maintenance of their vegetables business and for them to purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs they need. They are hoping that they will have a good yield and be able to increase their profit.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and other farm inputs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jessica Xiomara

texts.es: Jessica Xiomara C. P. reside en el departamento de La Libertad. Jessica tiene 22 años de edad, es soltera vive con sus abuelos maternos. Jessica es una joven ejemplar, a pesar de ser tan joven lleva consigo grandes responsabilidades como el cuido de sus abuelitos hasta la administración del hogar. Jessica curso hasta bachillerato, luego monto su negocio hace un año, una sala de belleza y venta de productos cosméticos, por la cual hoy solicita este crédito con el fin de surtir su inventario de productos de belleza .
texts.en:
Jessica Xiomara C. P. lives in the department of La Libertad. She is 22 years old, single, and lives with her maternal grandparents. Jessica is an exemplary young woman. Despite being so young, she already assumes great responsibilities ranging from looking after her grandparents to managing the household. Jessica completed high school and then started this business a year ago. She manages a beauty salon and sells cosmetics.

Today she is requesting a loan to restock her inventory of beauty products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock her inventory of beauty products

loans.name: Ndejje B Kisubi Agnes Group

texts.en:
K. Agnes is a businesswoman, forty-eight years old; she has three children studying and has three dependents studying, too.

Agnes has been dealing in the business of used-clothes and crafts, like mats, for over fifteen years. She is using the loan to purchase craft items such as material for making mats, hats, etc., and to purchase used clothes to sell.

Agnes is a hardworking and courageous businesswoman whose dream is the education of her children and the well-being of her family. She appreciates the loan because it is encouraging her to work.

loans.use: To purchase craft items and used clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase harvesting equipment

loans.name: Marta Lidia

texts.es: Marta Lidia V. O. reside en  Sta. María en el  departamento de Usulután. Marta tiene 42 años de edad vive solamente con sus cuatro hijas. Marta trabaja hace seis años en el negocio que inicio en su casa y ahora a transportado hasta el mercado regional de Usulután, ahora que Marta ha montado su  tortillería en el mercado, sus ingresos han ido mejorando notablemente, pero hoy se encuentra con el inconveniente de tener poca cantidad de insumos para sacar mas producción, es por eso que solicita de este crédito para comprar  mayor cantidad de materia prima y así lograr aumentar su producción al igual que sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Marta Lidia V. O. lives in Santa María in the department of Usulután. She is 42 years old and lives with her four daughters. For six years, she has been working at the business she started at home and later moved to the regional market of Usulután. Now that she has her tortilla establishment in the market, her earnings have improved dramatically.

Marta now faces the problem of having few supplies on hand to keep up with production. For this reason, she is requesting a loan to buy ingredients in bulk so that she can increase her production and reap the resulting profits.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Reziel

texts.en: Reziel P. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 27 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Reziel owns and operates a business cultivating fruit trees, like coconuts, and harvesting their fruit to process them for coco oil (copra). She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Reziel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Luaono

texts.en:
Luaono L. is a 36-year-old woman living in the town of Eva. She is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Luaono raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting bananas for sale. Luaono has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 650 Samoa tala (WST) a month from these activities.

Luaono joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luaono has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,750 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase harvesting equipment. Luaono  is now requesting a new loan of 2,500 WST, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fifth loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Luaono plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to financially support immediate members of her family.

Luaono was not affected by the tsunami that hit Samoa on Sept. 29, 2009.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu is a 60-year-old widow with four children aged between 13 and 22 years. She resides and owns a five-roomed house, where she is staying with four people. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.  

She owns a stall selling charcoal and bananas. She does her shopping from delivery vans, which get the items from villages. On average, she receives 10 customers a day. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for six years and with MCDT for 10 years. She is servicing her 17th loan, working with the same group mates. 

Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication. Her challenges include defaulters and the rainy season, because when it rains very few customers come to her stall since it is in muddy place. Nulu wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal and bunches of bananas. She is aspiring to see her business grow stronger and to start selling only on a wholesale basis.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal and bunches of bananas

loans.name: Zenny Aiza

texts.en:
Zenny Aiza A. is from the village of Catuan, Lunao, Gingoog City. She is 22 years old. Zenny Aiza is single. To make a living, Zenny Aiza operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. 

In 2009, Zenny Aiza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenny Aiza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Zenny Aiza from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Catuan, Lunao, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Savali

texts.en:
Savali T., a 35-year-old woman living in the town of Leusoalii, runs a general store selling a variety of different products in her community. She is married and has one small child. Savali has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 400 tala a month.

Savali joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 tala, which was used to expand the business, Savali is now requesting a loan of 2000 tala which will be used to renovate the business. This will be her fourth loan from SPBD. Savali plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in renovating a general store

loans.name: Ndejje B Nakayiza Mayi Group

texts.en: N. Mayi, a 30-year-old single woman, has been operating a beauty salon for three years so far. She is blessed with two children, who are in school, and she is looking after her mother in her home. She is using this loan to purchase salon items such as a drier, chemicals and hair extensions, etc. She praises our loan, since it is stress free. She is so encouraged and hardworking! Her dream is to educate her children and to attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase salon items such as a drier, chemicals, hair extensions, etc.

loans.name: Muava

texts.en:
Muava S., a 42-year-old woman living in the town of Salamumu, sells traditional handicrafts to tourists and members of her community. Muava was not affected by the tsunami which hit Samoa on 9/29/09. She is married and has two grown children. Muava has been in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 550 tala a month.

Muava joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Having successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 tala, which was used to purchase handicrafts to sell, Muava is now requesting a loan of 2000 tala which will be used to purchase additional handicrafts to sell. This will be her third loan from SPBD. Muava plans to use the additional revenue to financially support immediate members of her family.

About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional handicrafts to sell

loans.name: Geovanny Astul

texts.es: Geovanny Astul S. R. reside en el departamento de  Usulután junto a su esposa y su hija de 6 años de edad. Astul como le llaman sus familiares y clientes tiene 29 años de edad y se dedica al negocio que muchos sacrificios ha instalado, el ofrece servicios de reparación de motocicletas y vende piezas para motocicletas, el destino del crédito que solicita es para comprar herramientas que le hacen falta para el servicio de reparación de motocicletas en su taller.
texts.en:
Geovanny Astul S. R. lives in the department of Usulután with his wife and their 6 year old daughter. Astul, as he is called by relatives and customers, is 29 years old and has endured many sacrifices in order to start his business. He offers motorcycle repair services and sells spare parts.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy the tools he is lacking to make motorcycle repairs in his workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tools for his business

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario 48 years old and a resident of Jurisdiction Amulung Cagayan.  She is married to Celestino a local farmer in their village. They are blessed with four children: Rowena, who is 30 years old, a college graduate and is now working as an elementary public teacher in their village; Gilbert who is 28 years old, also a college graduate, and also a public high school teacher; Rolando who is 26 years old, also a college graduate and now is working as an Overseas Filipino worker in a factory in Qatar; and finally, Mary-Ann who is 19 years old, and is now  college student learning Information Technology.  Two of Rosario's children are already married.  

 
Rosario’s husband manages their farming business while Rosaerio is works in a general store business in their village.  At the general store, she earns a weekly income of PHP1,500. Recently, she has wanted her business to grow so that she can have an increase in her income. So, she is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP15,000 to purchase additional items such as sugar, canned goods, coffee, ten cases of bottled soft drinks, etc. She believes that this will really help her business and her family to have a progressing standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for her store

loans.name: María Silvia

texts.es: María Silvia G. de 43 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Usulután. María es una mujer soltera, actualmente vive en la casa de su tío don Julio de 75 años de edad. María es independiente económicamente trabaja en su negocio donde ha dedicado gran parte de su vida a él, es una venta de productos de uso personal como cosméticos y toda variedad de artículos para el cabello, ahora ella solicita de un crédito para comprar nueva mercadería para su negocio.
texts.en:
María Silvia G. is 43 years old and lives in the department of Usulután. She is a single woman who lives in the house of her uncle, Don Julio, who is 75 years old. María is financially independent and spends the majority of her time working at her business. She sells personal products such as cosmetics and a variety of items used for the hair. The loan she is currently requesting will be used to buy new merchandise for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase additional merchandise for her business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 50 year single mother of 2 children ages 30 and 32.  She resides and owns a five room house where she lives with four people. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.  

Mary owns a stall selling crafts in Mengo. She does her shopping from Kampala city and also from women groups in Mengo villages.  Her stall where she sells is on the outskirts of Kampala. On a typical day Mary receives 10 customers.  

Mary has been in the craft business for twenty years and she has been a client of MCDT for four years.  She is now servicing her eighth loan, and she is still working with the same group mates. 

Mary's monthly expenses include school fees and medication. Her challenges include defaulters and rainy season because when it rains very few customers come to her stall because it is in muddy place. Mary wants to use this loan to buy more crafts.  She is aspiring to see her business grow stronger and start selling only on wholesale basis.

loans.use: To buy more crafts for resale

loans.name: Kamu

texts.en:
Kamu E. is currently in the business of selling beer at her bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Kamu is 20 years old and is single.   With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to expand her business by stocking wines, Heineken beer, etc at her bar to sell.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie C. is 24 years old and operates a general store. Her 28-year-old husband, Crisante C., operates his own motorcycle business and works as a farmer. Margie does her best to fulfill her dreams and to make her business grow.  She works to have bigger profits to build their own house. At present, Margie, her husband, and their children live with her parents. 

Margie is not losing her hopes that some day she will fulfill her dreams. She wants to improve her business but she cannot make it because of insufficient capital. Therefore, Margie has joined the program and wants to borrow the amount of PHP 15,000 for additional capital to buy more items to sell.  She is hoping the KIVA lenders will give her consideration for her borrowing amount.

loans.use: To increase store inventory.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine P. is from Iligan City. She is 51 years old. Josephine is married and has 3 school-aged children. Josephine owns and operates a business selling home cleaning and other products to local community members. Josephine has been engaged in her business for more than 3 years and earns approximately PHP5,000 a month.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to improve her business. Josephine is requesting a loan of PHP 5000 to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional profits generated from the loan to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To increase stop inventory.

loans.name: Silvia Del Carmen

texts.es: Silvia Del Carmen S. S. de 39 años de edad  reside en Azatlan en el departamento de Usulután. Silvia vive con su esposo quien trabaja como comerciante y sus cinco hijos todos estudiantes. Silvia posee su propio negocio donde vende variedad de ropa para caballeros y carteras, el deseo de Silvia es poder surtir su negocio con nuevos productos ya que se acerca la época navideña donde hay más demanda de ropa, es por eso que solicita este crédito para comprar nueva mercadería para su negocio.
texts.en:
Silvia Del Carmen S. S. is 39 years old and lives in Azatlan in the department of Usulután. She lives with her husband, who works as a trader, and their 5 children who are all students. Silvia has her own business in which she sells men’s clothing and wallets. She hopes to restock her business with new products in time for the Christmas season when demand for clothing is higher. For this reason, Silvia is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase new merchandise to restock her business

loans.name: Emargelyn

texts.en: Emargelyn A. is from the village of Barangay 17, Gundaya, Gingoog City. She is 38 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children. Emargelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both vegetables from her garden and other products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Emargelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Emargelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. Emargelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children, to supplement the family income, and to reinvest in the business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

location.town: Barangay 17, Gundaya, Gingoog City, Misamis Orient

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita is 46 years old, married and blessed with a child named Jennifer. They are living happy in the village of San Andres Aurora, Isabela.  Estelita operates a sari-sari store business (community based store) in their village for four years.  She wishes for her business to grow for it is a great help in meeting the needs of their family.  With her income, she is able to assist her husband in earning an income.  

Now, she wants to borrow additional capital for her business since she needs more stocks for the improvement of her store. She is now in need of PHP18,000 and this will be used to buy more stocks to meet the demands of her customers.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks for her store

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary S. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.  Mary is 25 years old and is married to a business man. She has 5 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to renovate her house that has stayed with broken windows and doors for so long. She would one day like to rent it out.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela P. is from the village of Greenhills Suarez , Iligan  City. She is 43 years old. Angela is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Angela raises livestock (primarily pigs) for sale.  Angela has been engaged in her business for more than 5 years and earns approximately PHP 4000  a month.

In 2009, Angela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services.  She is requesting a loan of PHP5000 to purchase piglets and other young livestock to raise for future sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Angela from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand a livestock business

loans.name: Milagro Esperanza

texts.es: Milagro Esperanza M. R. reside en el departamento de Usulután. Milagro tiene 36 años de edad vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos, Víctor de 8 años y Edgardo de 3 años de edad. Milagro administra de su negocio el que inicio hace ocho años es una venta de productos de consumo diario, hace unos meses Milagro ha surtido su tienda con una pequeña venta de ropa, la cual ha tenido mucha demanda con sus clientes, ahora ella solicita de este crédito para comprar mayor cantidad de ropa para surtir su negocio y así generar mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Milagro Esperanza M. R. lives in the department of Usulután. She is 36 years old and lives with her husband and their two sons, Victor (age 8) and Edgardo (age 3). Milagro manages a business that she started 8 years ago in which she sells everyday consumer products. Eight months ago, she expanded her business and added a small clothing shop. Her products are in high demand with her customers.

Today Milagro is requesting a loan to buy clothing in large quantities so that she can increase her inventory and generate more income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing to add to her inventory of merchandise

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel A. is from the village of Barangay 26, Kahulogan, Gingoog City. She is 35 years old. Isabel is married and has 5 school-aged children. Isabel owns and operates a motorcycle repair shop for local community members. Isabel has been engaged in her business for more than 3 years and she earns approximately 6000 PHP  a month.

In 2009, Isabel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services.  She is requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.
