Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand a motorcycle repair shop.

location.town: Barangay 26, Kahulogan, Gingoog City, Misamis Orie

loans.name: Marta Esmeralda

texts.es: Marta Esmeralda R. De López reside en Santo Tomas en el departamento de San Salvador, Marta tiene 30 años de edad vive en casa de sus suegros con su esposo y sus dos hijos Gerardo de 14 años y Ronald 11 años de edad. Marta instalo su negocio hace seis años, el cual es administrado y atendido por ella, “Pupuseria Martita” nombre que lleva su negocio, tiene una clientela muy estable, la cual ha ayudado a Marta a generar ingresos con lo que ayuda a su esposo para los gastos de la familia, ella ahora solicita de este crédito con la finalidad de compara mayor cantidad de insumos para aumentar la producción de pupusas.
texts.en:
Marta Esmeralda R. De López lives in Santo Tomas in the department of San Salvador. She is 30 years old, married, and has 2 children – Gerardo (age 14) and Ronald (age 11). Marta and her family live in the house of her in-laws. Six years ago she started a business she manages herself called “Pupuseria Martita”, which is named after her. Marta has a stable clientele, which has helped her generate income and enabled her to help her husband with family expenses.

She is now requesting a loan so that she can buy supplies in large quantities and increase her production of pupusas.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for her business

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina E. sells fish at the local market and is requesting a loan to purchase onions and tomatoes to sell.  Regina is 29 years old and is married; her husband is a teacher. Regina has two school-aged children.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to pay the school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase onions and tomatoes for sale.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 27 years old and married to Nicholas who operates his own business. They have three children.

She manages a farm and sells milk from her livestock at the Seregeya market in Eldoret.

Jane was introduced to KADET by an existing borrower and is hoping to get a loan to buy more animal feed, including salt licks, for her calves. She also intends to use the proceeds to fund her children's education and buy a plot of land for her family.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy  more feed for her livestock

loans.name: Najjanakumbi J Namugamba Margaret Group

texts.en: N. Margaret, a 32-year-old married woman, has been selling charcoal for three years so far. She is blessed with four children and two dependents, all in school. She is a hardworking business lady whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house. She is using this loan to purchase bags of charcoal, trying to improve upon her business. Margaret is the president of this group.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal

loans.name: Rosa Lidia

texts.es: Rosa Lidia A. D. C. D. 50 años D. edad, resiD. en Cojutepeque municipio del departamento D. Cuscatlán. Rosa vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos graduados D. la universidad que son el orgullo D. Rosa. Ella maneja su negocio D. venta D. cosméticos con 14 años D. experiencia y también trabaja en la elaboración D. ropa a la medida. Rosa necesita D. un crédito para consolidar su negocio D. costura el cual tiene mucha demanda, pero no posee tela para elaborar ropa, es para ello el destino del crédito para invertirlo en telas y otros productos cosméticos para su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosa Lidia A. D. C. lives in Cojutepeque, in the department of Cuscatlán. She is 50 years old and lives with her husband and her two children. Both children have graduated from the university, and they are Rosa’s priD. and joy.

Rosa has had a business selling cosmetics for 14 years, and she also makes custom-tailored clothing. She needs a loan to consolidate the tailoring business, which has great demand. The loan will be used to buy fabric and also some cosmetics for sale.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric and cosmetics

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry P.'s main source of income comes from making and selling snacks and delicacies in her community. She is 44 years old, married and has three grown children. She is from the village of Lugait, Misamis Oriental. Cherry has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3000 pesos a month.

In 2009, Cherry joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Cherry is requesting a loan of 5000 pesos which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use her additional income to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Anjeanith

texts.en:
Anjeanith B. runs a sari-sari (variety retail shop). She is 35 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Boyogon, Medina. Anjeanith has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,600 pesos a month.

In 2009, Anjeanith joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Anjeanith has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 pesos from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.

Anjeanith is requesting a new loan of 11,000 pesos which will be used for working capital to raise poultry. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional income generated from the business to improve her house.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Working capital to raise poultry

loans.name: Jovie

texts.en:
Jovie is 27 years old and is married to Jay. Their family lives in the village of Jurisdiction Amulung, Cagayan. They are blessed with two children: Jayvee, who is 9 years old and is in second grade, and Jademar, who is 8 years old and is in first grade. They are enrolled in a public school in their village; the couple is hoping that, through their hard work, they will be able to afford to give their two children the education they need. 

Jovie is a hog raiser in her village. Through her patience and the sacrifices she's made to manage her business, she has been able to meet the needs of her family. Her husband is engaged in a manufacturing business; the profit he makes also helps sustain their family.

Jovie would like to borrow PHP 7,000 from Kiva lenders. She believes that this amount will help her business to grow.

loans.use: additional capital for her pig raising business

loans.name: Rosa Haydee

texts.es: Rosa Haydee M. C. reside en Cojutepeque municipio del departamento de Cuscatlán. Rosa tiene 45 años de edad vive con su esposo , sus dos hijos y su padre don Jesús de 76 años de edad. Rosa es una mujer muy trabajadora tiene una venta de pupusas y tortillas hace 13 años y ahora también ha montado una pequeña vitrina con productos de belleza para comercializar, la aspiración de Rosa es poder aumentar la demanda de sus productos de belleza, pero para esto necesita de más variedad,  y es por ello que solicita de un crédito que le permita invertir en su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosa Haydee M. C. lives in the Cojutepeque municipality in the department of Cuscatlán. She is 45 years old and lives with her husband, her two children, and her 76-year-old father, don Jesús.

Rosa is a hard-working woman who has operated a business selling pupusas (traditional Salvadoran dumplings) and tortillas for the last 13 years. Now, she has added a small showcase filled with beauty products for sale. Her goal is to increase the demand for the beauty products, but for this she needs more variety. That is the purpose of this loan.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory for beauty products business

loans.name: Najjanankumbi E Nakito Mary Group

texts.en: N. Mary is a thirty-eight year old single mother of five children, one of whom is still in school. She has a restaurant and a bakery. She is requesting a loan so that she can purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, tea, milk, etc. for her restaurant business. She is managing her home very well; with the loan, she will be able to educate the children and encourage the community to work. She is an enterprising business woman whose dream is to obtain her own plot of land.

loans.use: purchasing wheat flour, cooking oil, tea, milk, etc. for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina sells goods in the village of Marcos, Roxas, Isabela. She is married to Ricardo; they were blessed with three children, all of whom are married. Her income from her store really helps meet the needs of her grandchildren. She wants her business to make more of a profit so that she can continue to help her grandchildren.

Consequently, she wants to borrow PHP 10,000. It would serve as additional capital for her "sari-sari" (variety) store. Martina plans to buy additional goods for her store with the money. She is also planning to buy vegetables that she can sell in their village and thus have an additional source of income.

loans.use: purchasing more goods for her store and starting a new business

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is 21 years old. She is already married to Joey, who works as a barber in their village. The couple has no children yet; however, they are trying their best to save money for the children they will have in the future. The couple lives happily and peacefully in the village of Maluno Sur, Benito Soliven, Isabela.

Cristina has been running her livestock business ever since she got married. As she says, they need to have an additional source of income to meet their needs and to have something to use in case of emergency. Cristina aims to improve her business; consequently, she is asking to borrow PHP 4,000 for that purpose. She plans to buy food for her livestock so that they’ll be able to grow into healthy hogs. She hopes that this loan will allow her to gradually expand her business.

loans.use: purchasing food for her hogs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lobilina

texts.en:
Lobilina is a 39 year old businesswoman. She is married to Manny, a fisherman in their village. Lobilina is grateful that, through her husband’s business, they are able to have free viands sometimes. She hopes that they’ll continue helping each other to achieve what they aspire for their children. The couple are blessed with two children, Christian and Dian, both of whom are still studying. They live peacefully in the village of Maluno Sur, Benito Soliven, Isabela. 

Lobilina makes a living through her fruit and vegetable vending business. She has been in her retail business for three years; from selling, she generates an income of PHP 3,000 per month. She hopes that her business will further grow so that she can meet the needs of her family, especially her children. She wishes to borrow PHP 4,000, with which she will add some items to the store in order to earn more income.

loans.use: purchasing new items to sell

loans.name: Lona

texts.en:
Lona P. is currently in the business of selling cassava and Irish patatoes at the Konyokonyo market. She is requesting a loan so that she can purchase hens and roosters to sell. Lona is 27 years old and is married; her husband is a soldier. She has 3 children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and the empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchasing hens and roosters

loans.name: Savaandorj

texts.en:
Savaandorj A. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in the Arkhangai province of central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All three of his sons - ages 19, 15 and 13 - attend a local secondary school. A. currently operates a business making wooden products. He designs and produces many different styles and sizes of furniture that he sells throughout his community. 

A. started his business in 2002 with capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD) and has found success in his trade. Today, his business is well established in the local area, and his working capital exceeds 2,500,000 tugrugs (~1,750 USD). Regarding the future, A. says, "My main business goal is to continue to produce quality products for my customers." He is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug (~1,750 USD) loan to purchase more wood to make furniture.

loans.use: purchasing more wood to make furniture

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is a village store owner. She is married; her husband cultivates their small farm lot by planting rice and some vegetables. Due to high cost of commodities, Beatriz wants to acquire more products but cannot do so because she lacks business capital. Consequently, she wants to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 8,000.00. She will use the money to purchase more goods. She believes that this will enable her to improve her small "sari-sari" (variety) store and earn a higher income.

As parents, Beatriz and her husband are concerned with the future of their children. They sacrifice their time to support the needs of their four children, who are studying in tertiary and secondary education.

loans.use: improving her "sari-sari" (variety) store

loans.name: Saidat

texts.en:
Saidat is a 27 year old woman who is married with three children. She resides and owns a four room house where she is staying with four people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but, unfortunately, no running water.  

Saidat owns a stall selling second hand clothing. She works in Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala. On average she receives 10 customers a day. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for seven years; she is currently on her fourteenth loan, working with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication. Her challenges include defaulters and the rainy season because when it rains very few customers come to her stall since it is in a muddy place. Saidat wants to use this loan to buy more second hand clothes. She aspires to expand her business and eventually sell only wholesale.

loans.use: purchasing more second hand clothes

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel is a 29 year old who resides in the village of Maluno Sur, Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is happily married to Elmer, a driver in their village. They have two kids, both of whom are presently studying in elementary school. The couple hopes that their children will finish their studies in college someday.

Raquel owned and managed a village store even before she was married. According to her, her store is still growing and improving through time. She just needs additional capital to make it more profitable. She hopes to borrow PHP 5,000 for the continuous development of her retail business. This amount will be enough for her to use as additional revolving capital and it will definitely contribute to the growth of her business.

loans.use: developing her store

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena B. is from the village of San Juan, Gingoog City. She is 48 years old. Lorena is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lorena owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Lorena has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lorena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lorena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lorena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies and reinvest in her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: San Juan, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Zultai

texts.en:
Zultai B. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His wife works as a cook and has a monthly salary of 60,000 tugrugs (~42 USD). B.'s oldest son attends a local secondary school and his youngest is in kindergarten. 

B. currently operates a taxi service in his town. He first went into business in 2001 by transporting and delivering coal and firewood using his own truck. However, in 2006 the truck broke down and B. decided to buy a small car to transport people instead. He has found some success with his taxi, however, as many people in his town have started driving taxis in recent years, his profits have been decreasing. B. hasn't given up on his truck and hopes to make repairs and restart his transport business. 

B. is a very hardworking man who works every day until midnight. Although his profits aren't what they used to be, his earnings have enabled him to build a house for his family. For the future, he says, "I am trying hard to earn enough money to help my wife open a cafe." B. is requesting a 600,000 tugrug loan to purchase parts to repair his truck and some coal and firewood to sell.

loans.use: To repair his truck and buy some coal and firewood to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sela Ry Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group consists of 15 people, and they all live in Rumcheck village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sela R. has been selected by the members as the village bank president. 

She is a silk weaver, and now she wants to expand her business by purchasing more silk raw materials. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's quality of life with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Phang Seng KR., is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantatiO., he is a recycling collector. Mrs. Sela R. is 36 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more silk raw materials to support her business.

loans.name: Abondio

texts.en:
Abondio S. is currently in the business of selling beans, pulses and rice and is requesting a loan to purchase maize flour to sell. Abondio is 42 years old and is married with a husband who is a policeman. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up stores of her goods.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase maize flour to sell

loans.name: Najjanakubbi J Lidia Mulindwa Group

texts.en: Lidia M. is 36 years old, married with two children in school and also has two dependents in school. She has traded in used shoes for 13 years. She has been suffering from less capital and could not find any one to help her out. She is requesting a loan to purchase used shoes for sale. She wants to add to her business. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase used shoes for sale.

loans.name: Nazirhan

texts.en:
Nazirhan B. is 50 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His three children, two sons and a daughter, all attend a local secondary school. 

B. operates a livestock selling business in his province. He travels up to 200 km from his town to sell livestock throughout the province. In Mongolia it is common for a household to buy at least one cow and 10 sheep to be eaten during the long Mongolian winters. For that reason, B.'s business is particularly busy during October and November. 

B. started his livestock business in 2004 and has had steady growth over the years. To supplement his income, he also owns three cows that can produce up to 3 liters of milk per day. His wife sells the milk for 1,800 tugurugs (~1 USD) per liter. Selling livestock is hard work and B. works diligently to raise quality animals. He even produces all the hay necessary to feed his animals. He hopes to continue his success and says, "All I want is to save enough money for my children's education." He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more livestock to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock to sell

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is the responsible wife of Romeo. They live harmoniously in the village of Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. They are gifted with three children who are presently studying in secondary and elementary school. They want to send them to college and hope that they will become successful in the future. Despite the hardships and difficulties of life, they are still striving to support the needs of their children.

As a way of gaining income, her husband works in construction while Edna sells cooked viand (tasty dishes) and snacks inside the school campus of Nueva Vizcaya State University in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. As a fruit of her patience and sacrifices, she can earn a net income of 700 Philippine pesos per week, which she uses for their daily basic needs and for providing the allowances of their children. She wants to improve and continue her business so she is asking to borrow a loan of PHP14,000 to strengthen her capital for improving her small business.

loans.use: Additional capital for the improvement of her food-production business

loans.name: Irvy

texts.en:
Irvy B. is from the village of Lunao, Gingoog City. She is 37 years old and married with three children of school age. To make a living, Irvy owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $227 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Irvy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irvy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Irvy is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to invest in another business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
“If there’s a will, there’s a way." This is Elizabeth’s guiding principle in life. She knows that survival is hard unless a person makes an effort. Elizabeth is 30 years old and she is married to Michael, a fisherman in their village. They have no children yet but they see that as a positive reason to get prepared for their future. They believe that someday their children will have a good future with the help of their business, which is their main focus right now.

Elizabeth has been selling fruits and vegetables for a year now. She hopes that her business will continuously grow, so she is asking for additional capital to expand her business. She is requesting a loan of PHP4,000 so she can purchase more goods to offer to her customers. She hopes that her business will grow with the help of the loan that she is requesting.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Buyanbat

texts.en: Buyanbat C. is 28 years old and lives with his wife and two infant sons in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife is self-employed and manages a public bathhouse in a rented building. C. currently operates an electronics and appliances repair service in his town. He started his business in 2003 with the help of his wife, but has managed it alone since his wife started the bathhouse in 2006. C. is a very persistent and hardworking businessman. He has found success and is always planning for his business' future. His dream is to own his own electronics and appliance store. He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase electronic parts for his repair business.

loans.use: To purchase electronic parts for his repair business

loans.name: Akumu

texts.en:
Akumu J. is currently in the business of selling potatoes, like sweet and Irish potatoes, that have been imported from Uganda. She is requesting a loan to purchase fish to sell.  Akumu is 46 years old and married. Her husband is a policeman. She has five children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a rental house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth Akinyi

texts.en:
Elizabeth Akinyi is forty years old, married to Stephen Otieno, and a mother of five. She has been selling cereals in Kibuye, an open air market situated about 20 kilometres from Kisumu City, for the last two years.

She has been a member of an informal women's group, who assisted her with the start-up capital for her business. Elizabeth learned about KADET Ltd through a co-member in the women's group who is an existing client of KADET Ltd.

This is her first loan from KADET Ltd. She intends to use her loan to increase stock in preparation for the December festive season, when the region receives many visitors from the main cities.

She hopes to purchase and develop a plot of land in the neighborhood. 

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase her stock of cereals in preparation for December's high season

loans.name: Emilyn

texts.en:
Emilyn is a 37-year-old businesswoman. She is married to Elizalde who works as a driver in their village. They have two children and both of them are currently in school. Their family lives happily and peacefully in the village of Maluno Sur, Benito Soliven, Isabela.

Emilyn and her loving husband operate a transportation business in their village. According to Emilyn, she needs funds for the maintenance of their business. She therefore requests a loan of PHP5,000 for the repair of their motorcycle. Their income from the business is a big help to their family. That’s why she prays that her loan will be granted.

loans.use: For the repair and maintenance of their passenger motorcycle

loans.name: Perenlii

texts.en:
Perenlii D. is a 43-year-old single mother who lives with her two children in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. She and her children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her son currently lives and works in Poland, and her daughter attends high school at home.

D. operates a dairy products business in her town. She started her business in 2001 with capital amounting to 500,000 tugrugs, and has made much progress with her business over the years. When she started, she had very few reliable dairy suppliers and had to rely on friends in the countryside. However, with years of experience, she is now well established and has many reliable suppliers and customers. Today her working capital exceeds 1,500,000 tugrugs.

D. uses her earnings to support her family and says, "All I want is to provide my children with a happy and quality life." She is requesting a 725,000 tugrug loan to purchase more dairy products to sell through the winter and early spring, when the products will be in high demand.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products to sell through the winter and early spring when the products will be in high demand

loans.name: Mable's Group

texts.en:
K. Mable is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 56 years old and married with nine children, and she takes care of two more dependents. Mable is a business lady who has been selling hides and skins from Ibanda town for 12 years. 

Out of her transactions, Mable is able to make 400,000 UGX in profit a month, which helps to take care of her family with feeding, medical care, clothing and school fees. She has been successful because of her quality products that attract as many customers as possible -- even those from Kampala, which is about 300 kilometers away. 

She has a dream of expanding her business further by putting in more capital, hence increasing profit as well as having a happy family. Mable is a very hard-working lady and she needs a loan to help increase her business volume for more returns.

loans.use: Buying more hides and skins for her business expansion.

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
Mylene is 26 years old and a loving mother to her only son, Jodel. She is married to Jorell L., who is also 26. Mylene is short on capital, so she needs to borrow additional capital from the Kiva lenders amounting to Php 10,000, which she will use to buy additional goods to sell. She is hoping the Kiva lenders will help her by providing that amount. Mylene needs to improve her business because her family expenses are increasing nowadays. She wants to have savings while she is operating her business.

Her husband is busy doing their field activities. Sometimes he drives his tricycle for passengers. Mylene’s business is good for her. She walks around their village and sells meat, fish and vegetables. She believes in the saying “Patience is the key to success”. Whenever the weather is not good, she is still selling in their village because she wants to have more income for her family’s future.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Teleubai

texts.en:
Teleubai H. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a small house. His three older children currently attend a local secondary school and his youngest is in kindergarten. H.'s wife, Juldiz, is also self-employed and operates a clothing business.

H. operates a raw material trading business in his town. His major products are sheep and goat skins. H. started his business in 1999 by purchasing and selling animal skins in his local area. However, to take advantage of higher demand and profit potential, he now transports and sells the skins in Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and the capitol of Mongolia. He continues to make progress with his business and uses his earnings to improve his family's quality of life.

With the continued success of both of their businesses, H. and his wife hope to use their earnings to add on to their home. H. is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan to purchase raw materials for his animal skins business and coal for his own use.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for his animal skins business and coal for his own use

loans.name: Abeyi

texts.en:
Abeyi M. is currently in the business of selling radio tapes and video discs on the street and is requesting a loan to purchase radios to sell.  She is 39 years old and married to a husband who is a businessman. She has three children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up an electronic shop for selling computers, TVs, and so on.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase radios to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
“Through patience and sacrifices, we will survive.” These are words of encouragement from Erlinda, a resident of Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to a man named Benjamin, and they have one son and two daughters. Two of the children finished a vocational course and the youngest is still in college.

Her husband works as a construction worker in Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya, while Erlinda manages a small sari-sari store (a community-based general store) in their village as her way of helping her husband earn a living.  Since her income is not sufficient to meet the needs of her family, she wants to increase her business capital by borrowing a loan of PHP 14,000 from Kiva lenders.  This amount will be used to purchase different merchandise for her store.  With patience and sacrifices, and the continued support of Kiva lenders, Erlinda believes that she can improve her small sari-sari store.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for her general store

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina A., 27, lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is married with a child. She sells frozen foods and foodstuffs for a living. She has been in the business for 4 years. Tina is applying for a loan of N 150,000 to purchase more frozen foods and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Grace Makonjo

texts.en:
Grace is married to Festus. They have three children: Mathew (22 years old), Hellen (18) and Maureen (13).

Grace has been in the beauty salon business for six years. She was introduced to Kiva partner KADET through existing clients, and has no previous credit history. She services the residents of the estate where the salon is located.

Grace will use her loan to purchase a blow dryer for her salon. With the extra profits she earns as a result of having this equipment and therefore drawing more customers in, Grace plans to educate her children. In the future, Grace hopes to have a salon with all the necessary equipment and chemicals.  She believes she is determined and focused.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase a blow drying machine for her salon

loans.name: Mrs. San Choem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Seventeen people who live in Rumcheck village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan group. Mrs. San C. has been selected by the members as the village bank president, and they all will use the loan for different purposes. 

She is a weaver. She also is a pig breeder. Since her both business are going well, she wants to expand by purchasing more silk materials and to buy more piglets for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her business. Her husband, Mr. So R., is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a laborer. Mrs. San C. is 49 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a laborer while the other is attending the local school.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more silk materials and to buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette B. is from the village of Brgy. 26, Kahulogan, Gingoog City. She is 36 years old. Jeanette is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jeanette owns & operates a business venture in the food sector  by making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks such as the local delicacy called "kipping". Jeanette has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jeanette joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeanette has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Jeanette is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in renovating the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jeanette from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in renovating the business

location.town: Barangay 26, Kahulogan, Gingoog City, Misamis Orie

loans.name: Alule

texts.en:
Alule H. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs like matooke (cooked bananas), beans, etc., at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase cassava flour.

Alule is 41 years old and married. Her husband is a teacher, and they have 6 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by purchasing chickens and goats for restaurant use.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase cassava flour

loans.name: Habi

texts.en:
M. is a 47 year old widower who lives with his three children, aged 19, 17, and 11, in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. He and his three children live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son attends university, and the younger two children attend a local secondary school.

M. operates a raw materials business in his town where he sells iron, copper, aluminum and sheep and goat skins. He and his late wife started the business in 1995, but since his wife’s death last year, he has been working alone. M. works very hard to be able to provide his children with food and clothing, but he also wants to save enough money for his children’s tuition fees. He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan so that he can purchase not only sheep and goat skins for resale, but also coal for the winter in order to heat his family’s ger.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and goat skins for resale

loans.name: Joice Kavusi

texts.en:
Joice is 40 years old, married, and blessed with four children.

Her salon business is at the Junction in Eldoret.

She was introduced to KADET by another client. With the loan, she intends to buy more chemicals for her salon and also some equipment to assist her in running her business. In the future, she hopes to be able to improve her family's standard of living.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more chemicals and equipment for her beauty salon business

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Blessing is 35 years old and the mother of four children. She is a hard-working woman, and she is determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria, where she sells foodstuffs like bunches of plantains. She has been in the business for a long time. Blessing hopes for a loan of N150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 25-year-old businesswoman who runs a tailoring shop in Embakasi village in Nairobi. She has been in this business for two years now. She is requesting a loan of Kes.35,000 after successful repayment of an earlier loan to add to her stock of fabrics and purchase an additional sewing machine. She hopes to own a well-stocked boutique as she imports clothes in bulk and this loan will go a long way in facilitating this vision. She describes herself as hardworking and determined. 



About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to more than 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add to her stock of fabric and purchase an additional sewing machine

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina P. is from Iligan City. She is 60 years old. Avelina is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Avelina owns and operates a business venture in the food sector by making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community.  Avelina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Avelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Avelina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Avelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia S. is from the village of Salimpuno in the town of Sapang Dalaga. She is 45 years old. Lilia is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector by raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn and  cassava for sale. In 2005, Lilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the 6th cycle loan taken out by Lilia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family.
 About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Tseden-Ish

texts.en:
O. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest daughter, 11 years old, attends a local secondary school while the younger two children, 4 and 2 years old, stay at home. 

O. and her husband operate two businesses: the first, a used shoe retail business and the second, a restaurant. O. is mainly responsible for their restaurant, which they began in 2008 by purchasing an older restaurant in their town. Her husband is responsible for their shoe retail business, which they began in 2000 by renting a stall in the local market. Because of the success with their restaurant, they are planning on opening a second location in their town. 

O. is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more used shoes and other goods to sell in their stall.

loans.use: To purchase more used shoes and other goods to sell in their stall

loans.name: Rosefina

texts.en: Rosefina is 47 years old and already a widow.  She have two children: Jerome-19 years old, elementary graduate and Haydee-17 years old college student. Rosefina would like to develop her sari-sari store and restaurant so that she could be able to provide the needs of her family. Improving her business is what she wanted to earn bigger income. According to her, she would like to borrow additional capital amounting PHP8000 as her additional capital in purchasing more merchandise and development of her mini restaurant. She would be glad if her request will be granted.

loans.use: Additional capital for her restaurant business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia Y. is from the village of NHA, Balulang Cagayan De Oro City. She is 55 years old. Lydia is married and has 1 adult-aged child. To make a living, Lydia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling "Personal Collection" brand products in the local community. Lydia is just starting her business.

In 2009, Lydia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from HSPFI. Lydia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lydia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mrs. Nget Voeng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
A village bank, which consists of fourteen people, is located in Rumcheck village in Takeo province. All of the members will use the loan proceeds for different purposes.

Mrs. Nget V., a grocer by trade, is the village bank president. Her husband, Mr. Noul Ny, is a farmer who owns a 0.4-hectare plot of land on which he cultivates rice. He is also a cow middleman, and now he wants to expand his business. Thus, Mrs. Nget V. decided to seek a loan to buy more cows for her husband’s business. She is 49 years old, and she is the mother of a child who attends the local school.

loans.use: To expand her husband's business by purchasing additional cows

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
Adelina B. is from the village of Daan Lungrud, Gingoog City. She is 51 years old. Adelina is married and has 10 adult-aged children. To make a living, Adelina owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Adelina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Adelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Adelina is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Adelina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the house. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma C. is a resident of Brgy. Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old. With the support of her parents, she graduated with the Degree of Bachelor of Science in Accountancy. After this, she married to Francisco C. and they are blessed with five children.  Being responsible parents is their great obligation to support their children for their financial needs and moral support. 
Her husband is the one who manages their farm lots by planting variety of vegetables while Wilma engaged in selling herbal bath soaps and smoked fish in their village to help her husband in gaining income. With a small capital, she used to acquire her products from Solano Public Market and sell them to their village. Since her income is not sufficient to the family, she needs to earn more income to meet their daily needs especially for the schooling of their children. Due to lack of capital, she applied for loans from KIVA lenders, she is requesting an amount of P 5,000 to be added in her capital to acquire additional items to her products. She believes that through hard work and sacrifices, she could able to improve her small business and finance the schooling of their children.

loans.use: for purchasing additional items to sell

loans.name: Ronke

texts.en:
Ronke I. is 45 years old and she is a divorcee with a child. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells all types of sarongs, ladies bags and shoes; she has been in the business for five years. 

Ronke I. hopes for a loan of N150,000 to purchase more sarongs, ladies bags and shoes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Radnaa

texts.en:
O. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and four children in a house in the Zamiin-Uud province of Mongolia. All four of her children attend the university while she operates her building block and coal businesses. 

O. began her business in 2004 after moving from the Dornogobi province to the Zamiin-Uud province. She used her military retirement pension to begin her business, and since then, her business has been so successful that the earnings have allowed her family to build a house of their own. She is planning to expand her business in the future by producing more environmentally friendly fuel made from wood chips that do not have to be imported. 

She is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase more coal to sell during the upcoming winter season.

loans.use: To purchase more coal to sell during the upcoming winter season

loans.name: Victorina

texts.en:
Victorina "Vicky"  R. is a resident of barangay Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She was born on December 22, 1961 and finished her studies in college. Due to hardships and difficulties of life, she doesn’t want to get married yet. She still wants to help her parents and earn for their daily living.

Because of the tough competition and scarcity of job opportunities, Vicky then decided to be engaged in AVON, Natasha and MSE Cosmetics direct selling in their village.She sold her products to her friends and neighbors as well as to the villagers in their place that can afford to buy such commodities. As a fruit of her hard work and sacrifices, she was able to earn a net income of Php3,000 a month which they used to acquire their daily basic needs. She wants to save little by little for her future. Hence, she decided to improve her small business by acquiring more products. Since she has inadequate capital, she wants to borrow additional capital from ASKI amounting to Php5,000 for the further development of her business.

loans.use: additional capital in her direct selling business

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhorn P. lives in Ang Ta Kaut village in Takeo province. She is 30 years old, and she is the mother of three children. One of her children is enrolled in the local school, while her other children are too young to work or study.

To earn a living, she breeds ducks. Because her poultry business has been doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing 1,000 more ducklings and duck feed for breeding purposes. Her husband, Mr. Eam Vuth, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice. This couple also owns a small grocery store at home.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing 1,000 additional ducklings and duck feed

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lilian Adhiambo

texts.en:
Lilian Adhiambo is a 33-year-old married lady and mother of three. She operates a small shop in which she sells general household consumables (mostly food). She has been in this business for the last four years. It has picked up momentum after suffering disruption caused by the post-election violence of early 2008.

This is her second loan from KADET Ltd. She intends to use the money to increase the stock of her shop and also purchase cereals, in an effort to diversify. 

She aspires to open other outlets in the neighborhood to increase her income and to see her children through school.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase stock of cereals and foodstuffs.

Van M. is from the village of Southwestern Poblacion, Calamba Misamis Occidental. He is 39 years old. Van is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Van owns & operates a business venture in the food sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling of dried goods in the local community Van has been engaged in his business for more than 10 years. In 2007, Van joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.Van is requesting a new loan of 20,000.00 PHP which will be used to purchase additional capital of his existing business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Van from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of the borrower's family.
 About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. texts.en:
Marites C. is from the village of Catuan, Lunao, Gingoog City. She is 35 years old. Marites is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to reinvest in her business, as well as purchase food and medicine for her family.

loans.name: Baasanhuu

texts.en:
S. is a 43-year-old single mother of twin 16-year-old sons. She and her two children live in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family lives together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in one of the ger districts on the outskirts of the city. Her two sons attend university and she operates a clothing-making business in a rented room. 

She began her business in 2005 after working as a dressmaker in a local clothing factory. After several years of hard work and determination, her working capital now exceeds 400,000 tugrugs (~280 USD) with a monthly net profit of 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD). Her hope is to keep growing her business so that she can afford to pay her sons’ tuition and keep improving their quality of life. S. is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan to purchase a new, more efficient sewing machine and more clothing fabric for her growing business.

loans.use: To purchase a new, more efficient sewing machine and more clothing fabric for her growing business

Emerlina P. is from the village of Iligan City. She is 48 years old. Emerlina is married and has 11 school-aged children. To make a living, Emerlina owns & operates a business venture in the food sector by making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Emerlina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emerlina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Ya

texts.en:
Mrs. Ya S. is a 43-year-old married woman living in Sophy village in Takeo province. She has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the other children attend the local school. Her husband, Mr. Mao Thy, is shown on the left of the photo.

She uses rice to make wine to sell to her customers. She is also a pig breeder. Since her business has been doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing four more piglets and pig feed for breeding purposes. She hopes to increase her income and thereby improve her family's standard of living with this loan. Her husband is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice. Aside from this work, he is a also construction worker.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing four additional piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Frisca

texts.en:
Frisca E. is from the town of Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Frisca is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Frisca owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting rice for sale.

loans.name: Toolio

texts.en:
S. and her husband operate a retail store during the day. However, in the evening, S. operates her own clothing business. She makes a variety of deels, or traditional Mongolian coats. She is 28 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of Mongolia. Her oldest child, age 7, attends a local secondary school, while her youngest child, age 3, stays at home.

S.'s business has been so successful that it allowed her family to build a house of their own. Currently, her net profit is 200,000 tugrugs (~$140 US) per month and she wants to expand her clothing line to include dresses. S. is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~$420 US) loan in order to purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for her business.

texts.en:
Anne Waithera W.'s salon caters to local women, children and the occasional man. She offers plaiting, treatments, weaving and sells braids and hair chemicals. She has been in business for four years and she struggles with power outages, lack of water and lack of funds. She is using the proceeds of this loan to buy more hair products and another blow dryer. Her long-term business goals are to have a beauty training school and a larger salon with a massage room and a barber shop. 

Anne is a married woman who has three teenage children and serves as the guardian to two others. Her dream is to provide university education to her children so they can be employed and self-supporting.

loans.use: To buy more hair products and a new blow dryer

loans.name: Bayarsaikhan

texts.en:
U. operates a belt crafting business in his city. The belts he makes are worn with traditional Mongolian coats called deels. These deel belts are very elaborate, using leather, silver, turquoise and other expensive elements. U. learned how to make these belts from his grandfather when he was a teenager.

U. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and two children, ages 14 and 10, in the Chingeltey district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in one of the ger districts on the outskirts of the city. Both of his children attend a local secondary school and his wife works in a shoe factory and earns a monthly salary of 200,000 tugrugs (~$140 US).

U. began his business in 1999 and currently makes between 8 and 10 belts per month which earns him between 90,000 and 120,000 tugrugs (~$63-$84 US) in profit. U. is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~$350 US) loan in order to purchase a sewing machine for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine for his business

Mrs. Sa Vong L. is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field is infertile soil which has a bad effect on her crops. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the rice field. Her husband, Mr. Pen Hun, is a cow middleman. Mrs. Sa Vong L. is 48 years old and the mother of a child who is a grocer.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

texts.en:
Madelyn P.'s main source of income comes from selling scrap metal and other used products in her community. She is 20 years old, married and has a small child. They are from the village of Santiago, Iligan City. Madelyn has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 pesos a month.

In 2009, Madelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Madelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 pesos from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase products to sell. Madelyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 pesos which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mary Nyaboke

texts.en:
Mary Nyaboke M. is 32 years old and has a home bakery business. She offers cakes, porridge and mandasi (a donut-like pastry). She sells to rural residents and casual laborers in her area. She has been in this business for seven years and struggles with not having a permanent spot to bake and sell her goods. She is using the proceeds from this loan to buy an oven and open a shop. She would ultimately like to open a general store offering fish from Tanzania and clothes from Uganda. 

Mary is married and her husband works at Akamba bus services. They have four children, ages 5 to 14 years old. Mary dreams of educating all her children to the university level and buying her own home.

loans.use: To purchase an oven and open a shop

loans.name: Mrs. Phors Mouk Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phors M. is a pig breeder. She is 25 years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Reth Chhoen, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support their family. Thus, Mrs. Phors M. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and fertilizer. She will use the rest of the money to buy ice-creA. to resell. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's standard of living with this loan.

Mrs. Phors M. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. Mrs. San Nhorn is the group guarantor and she is also present in the picture with the village bank group. This village bank loan includes 17 people and they all live in Chhuon Srey village in TaK. province.

loans.use: To buy piglets, fertilizers and ice-cream to resell

loans.name: Morena Roxana

texts.es: Morena Roxana D. R.  de 40 años de edad reside en Antiguo Cuscatlán municipio del departamento La Libertad , vive  en la casa de su madre junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos de 15 y 5 años de edad, Morena es una persona que siempre ha apoyado a su esposo en todos los aspectos, hace seis años ella instalo su tienda para poder generar ingresos que ayudaran en los gastos familiares, ahora solicita de un crédito ya que carece de muchos productos que sus clientes solicitan, por medio de su ayuda Morena, podrá surtir su negocio y mejorar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Morena Roxana D. R., who is 40 years old, lives in Antiguo Cuscatlán, a municipality of the La Libertad district. She lives in her mother's house with her husband and her two children, who are 15- and 5-years-old respectively. Morena is the type of person who has always supported her husband in every way, and six years ago, Morena established her store to raise funds to help with family expenses. She is seeking a loan now because she has been lacking a lot of the products her clients have asked for. With your help, Morena will be able to supply her store and increase her profit.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies for her business

loans.name: Venie

texts.en:
Venie L. owns and operates a video games business. She is also a fish vendor. She is 45 years old, married and has four school-age children. They are from the village of Catuan, Lunao, Gingoog City. Venie has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 pesos a month.

In 2009, Venie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Venie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 pesos from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Venie is requesting a new loan of 5000 pesos which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the business as a reserve for future emergencies.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

location.town: Catuan, Lunao, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ogochukwu

texts.en: Ogochukwu is 20 years old and married with one child. She is a hardworking woman and she is very friendly to her customers. This has helped her to attract more customers to her shop. She hopes for a loan of 120,000 naira to purchase more electrical goods to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more eletrical goods

loans.name: Rom

texts.en: Mrs. Rom K. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from her plantation, she is a grocer. Mrs. Rom K. is a 49-year-old widow with three children: one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school. She lives in Tonle village in TaK. province. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more grocery products to resell to earn more profits.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to resell

loans.name: Víctor Manuel

texts.es: Víctor Manuel H. H.  de 28 años de edad vive con su esposa  e hija de 5 años de edad, originario del departamento de Cabañas donde aun reside con su familia. Víctor es un hombre muy inteligente ha montado su propio negocio con las capacidades y conocimientos que él conoce y domina sobre costura, el se dedica a la elaboración de ropa a la medida. En esta oportunidad el está solicitando de un crédito para comprar dos maquinas de coser ya que su demanda ha aumentado y  sus metas son instalar un mini taller de costura y así  poder hacer crecer su negocio al igual que sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Víctor Manuel H. H., who is 28 years old, lives with his wife and 5-year-old daughter. He is originally from the Cabañas district, where his family still resides. Víctor, a very smart man, has created his own business from his own skills and knowledge of the field of tailoring. He makes his living from the production of custom clothing. On this occasion, he is seeking a loan to buy two sewing machines because the demand for his services has increased. His goal is to establish a mini-tailoring workshop and thus be able to expand his business and his income.

Translated from Spanish by Julia Kastner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of two sewing machines

loans.name: Geronimo

texts.en:
Geronimo P.'s main source of income comes from selling scrap metal and other used products in his community. He is 27 years old, married and has a small child. He is from the village of Santiago, Iligan City. Geronimo has been in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 pesos a month.

In 2009, Geronimo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Geronimo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 pesos from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand his product offering. Geronimo is requesting a new loan of 8000 pesos which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his second loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: María Josefa

texts.es: María Josefa S. G. originaria de Tacuba del departamento de Ahuachapán, vive junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos quienes se encuentran estudiando. María instalo su negocio una tienda con productos de consumo aprovechando de la oportunidad que a los alrededores de su domicilio no cuenta con ninguna competencia, el negocio de María es muy conocido en Tacuba, son ocho años de experiencia que María posee en la administración de su negocio. El crédito que solicita está destinado para surtir su negocio con nueva mercadería.
texts.en:
María Josefa S. G. is a native of Tacuba, which is in the department of Ahuachapán. She lives with her husband and their three school-aged children.
