loans.name: United Friends Group

texts.en:
United Friends is a group of five borrowers led by James K. B., who is 23 years old and married with a six-month-old child. James is a 7th 
grade drop-out due to poverty. James and his family live in Ziggida Town, a small town close Zorzor, a district in Lofa county, in northern Liberia.

James’s business is the sale of palm oil. He buys palm oil wholesale from farmers, then bottles and sells it from a table to residents of Ziggida town. He has been running this business for two years and hopes to expand into selling wholesale. James sells quality palm oil and treats his customers well in order encourage them to continue buying from him.

James is a young fellow who is determined to do business, but because he is from a poor background, he has to work very hard for himself and his family. The sale of palm oil is the only means of financial support for James and his family. 
 
James needs this loan in order to purchase more palm oil wholesale so that he can acquire more profit for improving his business. He dreams of educating his child, continuing his own education and improving their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil wholesale, acquire more profit and improve business.

loans.name: Gibrilla

texts.en:
Gibrilla L. was born in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. He is thirty-five years old and is married to a business woman. Together they have four children. Three of their children are in primary schools; one child is in secondary school.

Gibrilla is requesting a loan of about 1,000,000 Sierra Leone Leone (SLL) in order to pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children.

loans.use: To pay his children's school fees and other school-related charges.

loans.name: Kiganda 4 Nakafero Robinah Group

texts.en:
N. Robinah is a cashier of her group loan. She is single and blessed with two children. She owns a dry-cleaning business and bakes chapatti (flat, unleavened bread) for sale. She is requesting a loan to purchase items to use in her dry-cleaning business and to pay those who help her wash, iron and maintain the clothes. 

She has stayed in her business of dry cleaning for 13 years so far. She is a hardworking businesswoman of 42. She is hoping for improvement in her business and in the well-being of her family. More so, her dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house of her own.

loans.use: To purchase items for her dry-cleaning business and to pay those who help her wash, iron and maintain the clothes

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha L. is 30 years old. She is married with 7 children, all of whom attend school. Her husband works as a secretary.

Asha is currently in the business of selling fish and tomatoes, and she is requesting a loan in order to purchase onions and cooking oil to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land and build property to rent out.


About BRAC

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase onions and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Peter Ndung

texts.en:
Peter Ndung N. has a hardware store called Petan Bricon Hardware & Electric. He has been in the business for five years and has three employees. He is located in an area with many upcoming construction projects.  

He plans to use the loan proceeds of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to renovate and expand his premises. Longer term, his goal for the business is to expand to offer other services, such as plumbing. He is ambitious and hardworking and in addition to his hardware business, Peter has a butchery and several rental houses. He is married and has two daughters, ages 5 and 11, and he wants them to get the best education possible.

loans.use: Renovation of his premises

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni L. is 30 years old. She is married with 4 children, all of whom attend school. Her husband works as a driver.

Poni is currently in the business of selling bedsheets and used clothes. She is requesting a loan to purchase saddles to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by stocking shoes and socks for sale.


About BRAC

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase saddles to sell.

loans.name: Kiganda 4 Namakula Rose Group

texts.en:
N. Rose, the group leader, is 30 years old. She is married, with 3 children in school.

For over two years, N. has had a retail shop that sells items such as sugar, rice, salt, and internet air time. She is an active business woman whose dream is to be a good example to her community and her family.

N. is requesting this loan in order to stock more items in her shop in order. She hopes to meet her customers’ needs and thereby expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase stock (such as sugar, rice, salt, and internet air time) to sell at a retail shop.

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Eliza E. is 42 years old. She is married with 6 children, all of whom attend school. Her husband works as a business man.

Eliza is currently in the business of selling bread and charcoal, and she is requesting a loan in order to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.


About BRAC

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy timber and materials for furniture making.

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily G. is currently in the business of selling cooking oil and is requesting a loan to purchase onions and tomatoes to sell. Lily is 23 years old and is married to a chief. She has three children who do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase onions and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Gnaling

texts.fr: Gnaling D. est une femme âgée de 48 ans, elle est divorcée et vit avec son enfant dont elle a la charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KAMBENG DOUMASSOU depuis 8 ans, elle y a bénéficié de 16 prêts qu'elle a toujours remboursés sans difficulté. Avec son crédit elle développe un petit commerce de tissu, de chaussures, de jus naturel du pays et de crème glacée. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de prendre son enfants en charge et de subvenir à ses propres besoins.
texts.en:
Gnaling D. is a 48-year-old divorced woman, and she lives with her child who is in her care.  For eight years, she has been a member of Banc Villageois de KAMBENG DOUMASSOU, where she has benefited from sixteen loans, each one repaid without difficulty.  With her current loan, she's developing a small business involving fabrics, shoes, natural country juices, and ice cream.  Her profits enable her to care for her children and to provide for their needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To further her business

loans.name: Nkere 4 Nampumba Molly Group

texts.en: N. Molly is 42 years old.  She is a single mother of two children who are all in school and four dependents she also manages to send to school. She will use this loan to purchase electrical devices like televisions, radios, cables, etc to sell. She has been in her business for two years so far. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase electrical devices like televisions, radios, and cables

loans.name: Judith Jepkemboi

texts.en:
Judith is 25 years old, married to Bernard and has one child. Her business, an electronic shop, is located within Eldoret Town.

She was introduced to KADET by another client. With the loan she is taking from KADET she will add more electronic goods to her stock. Her future dreams are to expand her business and fully support her family in meeting their basic needs.


About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add electronic goods.

loans.name: Lucia Mutheu

texts.en: Lucia Mutheu M. has run her beauty and barber shop for three years in a rural market area that is rapidly developing. She offers hair treatments, plaiting, blow drying, hair shaving, as well as manicures. The salon caters to men, women and children who visit the market. She has one employee, and the business is challenged by power rationing and water shortages. She is using the proceeds from this loan for an additional blow dryer and to add cosmetics and other beauty products to her line-up. She would ultimately like to own her own plot and salon building, as well as expand her offering. Lucia describes herself as hardworking, determined, and patient, and she is caring and loving to her family. Her husband works at Kenya Railways, and they have four children from age four to ten years old.

loans.use: To purchase an additional blow dryer and to add cosmetics and other beauty products to the offering

loans.name: Fe En Cristo 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Adrien is the coordinator of his group Fe en Cristo (Faith in Christ). His story is representative of both the members of his group and Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated from Haiti) clients more generally. His group is based in the areas surrounding Santiago, the second largest city in the DR. Santiago's economy is agricultural and the region is famous for tobacco and beef, despite these benefits, many of the region's poor, including the members of this group have limited access to running water (none of which is potable) or electricity. It is in these conditions that Adrien makes his home as a single father with his 7 year old daughter. 

Adrien is excited to take his first loan with Esperanza. He will use this loan to invest in a business selling used clothing which he will buy in bulk to get a better price. He hopes that this loan will help him build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for his daughter. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: Bulk packages of used clothing

loans.name: Charles Otieno

texts.en:
Charles is married to Beatrice, and they have five children: Marion (17 years old), Millan (14 years old), Talash (10 years old), Tracy (5 years old), and Angela (1 and a half years old).

Charles has been in the tailoring business for fourteen years. He was introduced to KADET by existing groups, and he has no previous credit history. His area of business is in a stall within the market, and the market is situated in a highly populated area. Charles wants a loan to buy a stock of materials in readiness for the Christmas holiday season and festivities.

With the extra profits, Charles plans to buy an overlock sewing machine, which he hopes will help him with his tailoring business. He describes himself as hardworking.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: To buy a stock of materials in readiness for the Christmas holiday season and festivities

loans.name: Momodu

texts.en: Forty-one years old Momodu C. is seeking a loan of 1,000,000 SLL for the first time from Kiva through SMT. He wants a loan in order to pay school fees and other school related charges for his children, to invest in his wife’s business, and also to invest in his farm by paying laborers. Momodu’s wife sells palm oil and rice, and his two children are in Junior Secondary School II.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children, to invest in his wife's business, and to invest in his farm by paying laborers

loans.name: Masajja E Nakalema Sarah Group

texts.en: N. Sarah is thirty-nine years old. She is married and has four school-age children. She deals in brick making and also in the selling of fresh foods. She has been in her business for seven years. She is using this loan to purchase fresh food to sell (such as cassava, bananas, sweet potatoes, and Irish potatoes) and for bricklaying expenses. She hopes the loan will enable her to improve upon her business by adding more stock in the business. She is so encouraging and hardworking, and her dream is to obtain a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase fresh food to sell and for bricklaying expenses

loans.name: Try And See Group

texts.en:
Try and See is a group of five borrowers led by Korpo K. G., who is 45 years old and married with five children between the ages of 15 and 30. Their educational levels are 7th to 12th grade. Korpo herself is illiterate due to poverty. She and her family live in Ziggida Town, a small town close to Zorzor, a district in Lofa county, in northern Liberia. Korpo’s business is baking. She buys baking materials and ingredients like flour, sugar, baking powder, eggs and butter to bake and sell to residents of Ziggida town. She has been running this business for three years and hoping to expand to a larger bakery. Korpo’s bread, doughnuts and other baked goods are very nice as well as affordable, which encourages her customers to continue buying from her.

Korpo started her business with a small fund saved during the civil crisis, but because of family responsibilities, Korpo has been facing some financial constraints. She needs this loan in order to purchase more baking ingredients so that she can continue to bake and serve customers and improve her business. Korpo dreams of educating her children and giving her old-age husband the best of support.

loans.use: To purchase more baking ingredients so that she can serve her customers and improve business.

loans.name: Massaja E Namuyomba Aisha Group

texts.en: N. Aisha is a hardworking businesswoman. She is twenty-nine years old and married with three school-age children. She has been operating a restaurant business for seven years. She wants to use the loan to purchase a fridge and utensils in order to add capital to her business. She hopes for improvement in her business. She wants to obtain a house and a car and to provide an education for her children.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge and utensils in order to add capital to her business

loans.name: Marie's Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are Marie C., Issa J., Ramatu K., and Yeabu K.. They named their group "Marie's Group" after the group's leader. They are small scale businesswomen based in the city of Makeni who have come to SMT/Kiva to seek their very first loan. They are requesting a loan of 500,000 SLL each to enable them to expand their businesses.

Marie C. is the leader of this group. Marie was born in Makeni thirty-five years ago. She is married to an architect, and they have three children. One of their children is in Junior Secondary School III (JSS III), another is in class two, and the last child is not of school going age. Marie sells fried food and has been in the business for many years.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Na True Dae Last Group

texts.en:
Here are Osman C., Kadiatu C., Zainab C. and Memuna K.. They named their group Na True Dae Last.  They are small scale business people in Makeni, in northern Sierra Leone. These entrepreneurs are seeking a loan of Le 500,000 each to enable them increase the size and quality of their businesses. 

The leader of this group is Osman C.. He is standing in the middle of the group. Osman is 45 years old.  He is married to a businesswoman and the two of them have three children, one in class five, the other in class six. The last one is not of school going age yet. Osman sells ground-nuts/peanuts, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), beans and other such items.  Osman has been in this business for more than ten years now.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Nabisalu 5 Nasubuga Florence Group

texts.en: Florence N. is a 26 year old single woman blessed with two school-age children.  She is the president of her group. She has been running a salon since 2007.   She will use this loan to purchase chemicals, hair extensions, hair foods, etc.  She will also be able to add capital to her business. She is a hardworking business lady whose dream is to educate her children and raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals, hair extensions, hair foods, etc.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene C. is a 29-year-old single mother of three children: Lynus (6yrs), Sandra (4yrs) and Faith (1yr). She lives in Kapchebar Village.

Irene learned about KADET through a World Vision meeting she attended in Tambach. She has not borrowed a loan from any other MFI apart from KADET Ltd.

Irene owns a posho mill (turning corn to maize flour) and sells cereals like maize and beans. She has previously borrowed a loan of Kshs 50,000 from KADET Ltd and paid it back well. Irene plans to use this new loan to expand her business by purchasing farm inputs to plant beans and vegetables for sale. She also intends to venture into the dairy business by buying a dairy cow. Irene sells her goods to schools and individuals.

If this loan boosts her business, Irene intends to buy a piece of land to construct a house.

Irene describes herself as talkative and joyful. She dreams of building a campsite on her farm in the future.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Irene wants the loan to purchase farm inputs and a dairy cow

loans.name: Never Break Down Group

texts.en:
Never Break Down is a group of 5 borrowers led by Yassah W., who is 40 years old and married with 6 children.  Her children are aged 1-20 and their educational levels are kindergarten - 10th grade.  Yassah is illiterate due to poverty.  

She and her family lives in the Ziggida Town, a small town close to Zorzor, a district in Lofa county, northern Liberia.

Yassah’s business is the sales of general goods like bar soap, pomades, sugar, milk, etc.  She buys general goods wholesale and sells retail in a small shop to residents of Ziggida town Lofa County, northern Liberia.

She has been running this business for 3 years and is hoping to improve to a bigger shop. Yassah talks to her customers in a good manner and sell good products in order encourage them to continue buying from her.

Yassah has been facing financial constrains with her business, because she is responsible for the daily expense of her family.  Her husband is jobless. She needs this loan in order to purchase more general goods wholesale to improve business.

Yassah dreams of giving her children a better education and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more general goods wholesale to improve business.

loans.name: Rokhaya

texts.fr: Rokhaya S. est une femme de 39 ans elle est divorcée et vit avec ses 5 enfants dont elle a l'entière charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KAMBENG DOUMASSOU depuis 2 ans et demi. Elle développe une activité de vente de tissu teinté et de chaussures. C'est avec les bénéfices générés par son petit commerce qu'elle assure la prise en charge de ses enfants
texts.en:
Rokhaya S. is a 39-year-old divorced woman who lives with her five children whom she alone supports.  She has been a member of Banc Villageois de KAMBENG DOUMASSOU for 2½ years.  Rokhaya is developing a business selling shoes and dyed cloth.  With the profits generated from her small business, she ensures that her children are cared for.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To further her business

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera is a widow with one daughter. She runs a small business selling various cosmetic items: shampoos, soaps, detergents, etc. She has been in this business for 17 years. When Vera's husband died, she had to continue the business that he initially started. She worked hard, learned a lot and finally was able to sustain the business and even open several more locations to make this business a success.

Vera would like to borrow 12,000 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventories. Her business goal is to open one more location in her town. She wants to save enough money to be able to help her daughter to study at college.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of inventory

loans.name: Nabisalu V Nansumba Christine Group

texts.en: N. Christine is fifty years old and is representing her loan group. She is widowed with four children, all in schooling, and she also has four dependants in schooling too. She has been operating a clinic business for over eight years. She is using the loan to stock medicines in her clinic to meet her customers’ needs. She is a hard-working businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To stock medicines in her clinic to meet her customers’ needs.

loans.name: Antony Mwaura

texts.en:
Antony is 34 years old, married and is blessed with three children. 

He runs a vehicle garage business and his business is located within Eldoret Town. 

He was introduced to KADET by a member of Jubeta self help group which was already an existing group at KADET. He has applied for a loan which he intends to use to add more materials for his vehicle repair business.

With the extra profit he plans to expand the business that the wife operates.

In future he hopes to improve the living standards of his family.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more materials for his vehicle repair business

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline C. is a 48-year-old woman who is married to Micah C.. She has been blessed with seven children.

Pauline has a shop in which she sells general merchandise like sodas, clothes, sugar, cooking fats, and other items. Her business is located in Pemwai Town Centre. Most of her customers are Pemwai residents.

This is Pauline's ninth loan from KADET, and she has not had any loans from other microfinance institutions apart from KADET. Pauline intends to use this loan to restock her shop, to purchase dairy cows for a milk supply, and to pay school fees for her children.

If this loan boosts her business, Pauline intends to construct a poultry house to enable her to keep poultry.

Pauline dreams of expanding her business, making her children excel, and becoming a millionaire. She describes herself as hardworking and ever-anxious to come up with new business ideas.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop, to purchase dairy cows for a milk supply, and to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Favour Group

texts.en:
Favour group is a group of 5 borrowers led by Korto M., 40 years old, married with 7 children aged 10-22 years old. Their educational levels are 5th-9th grade. Korto is an illiterate due to poverty. She and her family live in Ziggida Town, a small town close to Zorzor, a district in Lofa county, northern Liberia.

Korto’s business is the sale of general goods like candles, matches, batteries, foodstuffs, etc. She buys general goods wholesale and sells retail on a table to residents of Ziggida town. She has been running this business for 7 years and is hoping to expand to a bigger table.

Korto sells quality goods in order encourage customers to continue buying from her. She was a farmer but later decided to get into business because farming in Liberia is a very poor business because most people make farms just to feed their family.

Korto needs this loan in order to purchase more general goods wholesale to improve business. She dreams of giving her family a better living standard.

loans.use: to purchase more general goods wholesale to improve business

loans.name: Barracks 2 Nakalebe Florence Group

texts.en: N. Florence is a hardworking businesswoman of forty-six years old. She is widowed with two children, and she has five school-age dependents. She deals in the charcoal business, and she has been in her business for four years. She is requesting this loan to purchase bags of charcoal, at least over fifty, to add stock in her business, which will also add capital to her business. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to complete her rental houses to enable her to manage her family well and educate the children (dependents).

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal, at least over fifty, to add stock in her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of iron for the manufacture of hoes

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es:
Bertha es una socia dinámica y colaboradora, vive en la ciudad D. Pucallpa región D. Ucayali, tiene 46 años, es madre D. siete hijos, D. los cuales cinco son mayores D. edad, ella se dedica a la venta D. menús (comida), su restaurante está ubicado en el centro D. esta localidad, en este negocio trabaja junto a una D. sus hijas, cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo, él es agricultor. 
Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al 2000” desD. hace dos años, el primer crédito que recibió fue D. 300 soles, dinero que invirtió en artículos para su bodega.
Actualmente ella necesita un crédito D. 1200 soles, que será utilizado para comprar arroz, azúcar, carnes al por mayor. La meta D. Bertha es tener un local propio para su restaurante, ya que el que tiene es alquilado.
texts.en:
Bertha is a dynamic, cooperative member who lives in the city of Pucallpa in the region of Ucayali. She is 46 years old and the mother of seven children, of whom five are grown. She works selling meals in her restaurant which is located in the center of the town. In this business she works with one of her daughters and counts on the help of her husband who works in agriculture. She has been part of the Community Bank "Women of 2000" for two years. The first loan she received was for 300 soles, money she invested in articles for her storeroom. Currently she needs a loan of 1200 soles which will be used to buy rice, sugar, and meat at wholesale. Bertha's goal is to have her own location for her restaurant since she rents the place she has now.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, and meat at wholesale

loans.name: Mirian Janett

texts.en:
This is Mirian. She is part of a communal bank consisting of 16 neighbors who live in Cusco. The group is called Santa Rosita de Lima, named after a Virgin of Peru. She is a native of Cusco.

Mirian is 38 years-old. She lives with her partner and two children. One child is two years-old and the other is in high school. Mirian is a sales representative for a food distributor in Peru. She sells groceries such as milk, Pampers, toilet paper, etc. With the loan, she will buy materials to fix the windows and doors of her house which will improve the quality of life of her family.

Mirian appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to make the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To remodel her home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase corn for stockpiling

loans.name: Odisa

texts.es:
Odisa es una mujer perseverante y activa, vive en la ciudad D. Pucallpa región D. Ucayali, tiene 43 años, es madre D. cinco hijos, D. los cuales dos son mayores D. edad, ella se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes al por menor, tiene una bodega en su casa, también se dedica a la elaboración D. carbón, cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo, que se dedica a la compra y venta D. tablas. Odisa forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las Claritas 2” desD. hace un año y cuatro meses, el primer crédito que obtuvo fue para invertir en gaseosas para vender.
En la actualidad ella necesita un crédito D. 1000 soles, que será utilizado para comprar productos para su bodega (arroz, azúcar, fideos, detergente, etc.), ya que recién esta empezando con este negocio y necesita surtirlo. El sueño es tener una tienda bien implementada, con artículos para toda ocasión.
texts.en:
Odisa is a perseverant and active woman. She lives in the city of Pucallpa in the Ucayali region. She is 43 and has five children. Two of the children are adults. She sells retail groceries. She has a convenience store in her house. She also manufactures coal. She counts on her husband’s support. He buys and sells lumber. She has been part of the Las Claritas 2 Communal Bank for one year and four months. She used her first loan to buy soft drinks to sell. She currently needs a loan for 1,000 PEN to buy products for her convenience store (rice, sugar, noodles, detergent, etc.). She has recently started this business, and she needs to stock it. Her dream is to have a store that is well set up with articles for every occasion.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for her convenience store (rice, sugar, noodles, detergent, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase ointments and cosmetics

loans.name: Barracks 1 Tendo Max Group

texts.en: Group leader T. Max is a business woman of twenty-six years-old, married with one child and two additional school-age dependents. For the last four years, she has had a cosmetics business. The products are now more expensive so she requires more capital for her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase products such as chemicals, lotions, creams, etc. and she will expand her business. She feels with the loan that she will have the strength to work and be encouraged to work harder. She is a hard working woman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products for sale.

loans.name: Rosula Rosario

texts.es: Rosula Rosario es una persona perseverante y creativa, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa, región de Ucayali, tiene 37 años y es madre de cuatro hijos todos menores de edad, ella se dedica a la confección de carteras de telas y bisutería, su pequeño taller funciona en su casa, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo que se dedica a la compra y venta de madera. Integra el Banco Comunal  “Las Perlas de Manantay” desde hace un año, el primer crédito que obtuvo fue de 300 soles que le permitió invertir en telas, ahora necesita un crédito de 1200 soles que será utilizado para comprar telas, cintas, hilos, piedras para la confección de carteras. La meta de Rosula es tener un taller de costura bien implementado  y así ofrecer trabajo a otras mujeres.
texts.en:
Rosula Rosario is a creative and tenacious person who lives in the city of Pucallpa, in the Ucayali region. She is 37 years old and is the mother of 4 minor children. She is engaged in the business of making fabric handbags and jewelry; her small workshop is in her house. She has the support of her husband, who buys and sells wood. She has been a member of the communal bank “Las Perlas de Manantay” for a year. The first loan that she obtained was for 300 soles, which she invested in fabrics. Now she needs a loan of 1200 soles that will be used to buy fabrics, ribbon, thread, and beads to use in making the handbags. Rosula's goal is to have a well-equipped sewing shop where she can offer work to other women.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fabric, ribbon, thread and beads for the production of handbags

loans.name: Bruno

texts.en:
This is Bruno. He is part of a communal bank consisting of 16 neighbors who live in Cusco. The group is called Santa Rosita de Lima, named after a Virgin of Peru. He is a native of Cusco.

Bruno is 37 years-old. He lives with his partner and their eight year-old child. Bruno sells wholesale and retail clothing in different places in Cusco. With the loan, he will buy more clothing from Bolivia and Lima to sell.

Bruno appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to make the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell.

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz es una mujer dinámica y trabajadora, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 63 años, madre de cinco hijos todos mayores de edad, ella es viuda desde hace muchos años, Luz se dedica a la venta de granos de la región y también tiene un motocarro que lo alquila diariamente. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al Progreso” desde hace ocho años, el primer crédito que recibió lo invirtió en la compra de pollos para vender en el mercado de Bellavista de esta localidad, actualmente Luz necesita un crédito de 3000 soles que lo utilizará en la compra de maíz  para llevar a vender a la ciudad de Lima.  La meta de Luz es tener una tienda de abarrotes en general y seguir trabajando para mejorar económicamente.
texts.en:
Luz is a dynamic and hard-working woman. She lives in the city of Pucallpa in the Ucayali region. She is 63, and she has five children who are adults. She has been a widow for many years. Luz sells regional grains. She also has a “motocarro” (three wheeled motorized vehicle), which she rents out daily. She has been part of the Mujeres al Progreso Communal Bank for eight years. She used her first loan to buy chickens to sell in the local Bellavista market. Luz currently needs a loan for 3,000 PEN to buy corn to take to the city of Lima to sell. Luz’ goal is to have a general grocery store and to keep working to improve economically.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wholesale corn

loans.name: Ruth

texts.fr: Ruth Z. est une femme de 33 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle habite à Assahoun une ville située à 70 kilomètres  de Kpalimé. Elle est coiffeuse-tresseuse - manucure-pédicure. Elle exerce ce métier il y a 7 ans. Avec ce prêt, elle voudrait acheter les mèches avec lesquels elle aimerait tresser les clients. Avec les bénéfices réalisés, elle souhaiterait bien prendre soins de sa petite famille.
texts.en:
Zebede Ruth is a woman of 33 years, married with 2 children. Assahoun She lives in a town 70 kilometers of Kpalime. It is a hair braiding - manicure-pedicure. It performs this job there 7 years. With this loan, she wants to buy the locks with which she would weave customers. With the profits she would take good care of his family.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy match for coifure

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel es una mujer activa y muy colaboradora, vive en la ciudad D. Pucallpa región D. Ucayali, tiene 72 años, madre D. ocho hijos, todos mayores D. edad, se dedica a la venta D. ropa D. segundo uso en el mercado D. Bellavista, en este negocio también participa su esposo. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las Innovadoras” desD. hace ocho años, el primer crédito que recibió fue D. 300 soles que le permitió invertir en gaseosa y golosinas para vender.
Ahora Isabel necesita un crédito D. 1000 soles que será utilizado para comprar ropa D. segunda por fardos. La meta D. Isabel es tener una tienda D. artículos para el hogar.
texts.en:
Isabel is an active woman who works well with others. She lives in the city of Pucallpa in the Ucayali region. She is 72 years old and the mother of eight children, all of whom are adults. Isabel sells second hand clothing in the Bellavista market together with her husband. She has been a member of the communal bank “Las Innovadoras” for eight years. Her first loan was for 300 soles, which she invested in soft drinks and sweets to sell. Now Isabel needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy bundles of second hand clothing. Her goal is to have a home goods store.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bundles of used clothes

loans.name: Luchnado Por El Progreso 3 Group

texts.en:
Mimosa is the coordinator of her group: Luchando Por El progreso (Fighting for Progress). Her story is representative of both her group and Kiva partner Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated from Haiti to the Dominican Republic) clients more generally. Her group is based in the areas surrounding La Romana where the economy centers around the sugarcane harvest and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable at best. Here she makes her home as a single mother of two children.

Mimosa is excited to take her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her first without problems. She plans to use this loan to invest in new merchandise for her clothing business. She will purchase six pairs of pants, four blouses, three skirts, 12 pairs of panties and 12 pairs of men's underwear. By making a large purchase she can negotiate a better price and make a healthy profit. With the profits she plans to continue constructing her house and to proviD. better food for her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase electrical equipment

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
Ana María es una mujer trabajadora, vive en la cuidad D. Pucallpa región D. Ucayali, tiene 65 años, madre D. siete hijos, todos mayores D. edad. Anita se dedica a la venta D. menús (comida), este negocio lo realiza en su casa, ella da pensión a unos trabajadores D. construcción civil. 
Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las  Ucayalinas” desD. hace cinco años, el primer crédito que obtuvo fue D. 300 soles, que fue utilizado para comprar abarrotes y vender, actividad que ya no realiza.
Actualmente ella necesita un crédito D. 1500 soles que será utilizado para comprar productos e insumos para la elaboración D. sus comidas, ya que ella cobra semanalmente a sus comensales (clientes). La meta D.  Ana María es tener un restaurante bien implementado.
texts.en:
Ana Maria is a hardworking woman who lives in the city of Pucallpa in the Ucayali region. She is 65 years old and the mother of seven children, all of whom are adults. Anita sells “menú” (plates of food) for a living. She works out her home and pays a salary to a few to a few civil construction workers. She has been part of the comunal bank “Las Ucayalinas” for five years. Her first loan was for 300 soles with which she bought groceries to sell. She is no longer in that business. Isabel now needs a loan of 1500 soles to buy products and supplies to make her meals, since she charges her clients on a weekly basis. Ana María’s goal is to have a well established restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies to prepare meals

loans.name: Valerio

texts.en:
This is Valerio. He is part of a communal bank consisting of 16 people living in Cusco. The group is called Santa Rosita de Lima, named after a Virgin of Peru. He is a native of Cusco. He is 59 years-old and unmarried.

Valerio works in a beer factory and also has a side business selling fertilizer. With the loan, he will augment the capital invested in his fertilizer business. The business fluctuates – sometimes he sells a great deal, sometimes a little and sometimes nothing at all.

Valerio appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to make the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy more fetilizer to sell.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es: Sandra es una mujer perseverante y dinámica, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 39 años, es madre de un hijo menor de edad. Sandra se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza y a la crianza y venta de pollos, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo quien es trabajador independiente. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las Innovadoras” desde hace tres años, el primer crédito que obtuvo fue de 300 soles que invirtió en la compra de ropa interior para damas, en la actualidad Sandra necesita un crédito de 1000 soles que será utilizado para comprar productos de belleza y artículos de lencería. Su sueño es tener una tienda de prendas de vestir bien surtido.
texts.en:
Sandra is a dynamic and persistent woman. She lives in the city of Pucallpa in Ucayali region. She is 39 years old and the mother of a dependent child. She sells beauty products and breeds chickens for sale. Sandra has the support of her husband who is self-employed.

She joined the Communal Bank “Las Innovadoras” (The Innovators) three years ago. Her first loan of 300 soles was used to buy ladies’ undergarments. At the moment, Sandra is requesting a loan of 1000 soles in order to buy beauty products and lingerie. She dreams of owning a clothing store that is well stocked.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products & lingerie

loans.name: Nuevo Progreso Group

texts.en:
Maria lives in the crowded capital of the Dominican Republic where traffic jams and heat are more reliable than electricity and water. She is the group coordinator of Nuevo Progreso and is currently looking to take out her third loan.

With this loan Maria will buy used clothing that comes wrapped in large, plastic packs and are imported from other countries. InsiD. there is a variety of different clothes and sizes which she will then resell to her customers for a profit. This loan will give her the initial capital to buy these packs, which would be very hard to come by otherwise.

With her increased earnings, Maria hopes to be able to buy more food to properly nourish her young children. In the long run she would like to earn enough to buy her own home in order to have a more stable location to raise her family. She would like to thank you all for your support!

loans.use: To buy packs of used clothing to sell

loans.name: Development Group

texts.en:
'Development' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Gayduo A., 35 years old and a widow with 3 children aged 12-20 years old. Their educational levels are 4th-10th grade. She is an illiterate due to poverty. Gayduo and her family live in Ziggida Town, a small town close to Zorzor, a district in Lofa county, northern Liberia.

Gayduo’s business is the sale of palm oil. She buys palm oil wholesale from farmers and sells retail on a table in bottles to residents of Ziggida town. She has been running this business for 3 years and is hoping to expand to selling wholesale. Gayduo sells quality palm oil and treats her customers in a good way in order encourage them to continue buying from her.

During the Liberian civil crisis, Gayduo and her husband lost everything they had, but after the war ended she decided to get into business and started selling prepared food, but in late 2006 she started selling palm oil which is better than other businesses she was in. The sale of palm oil is the only means of financial support for Gayduo and her family.

Gayduo needs this loan in order to purchase more palm oil wholesale to acquire more profit to improve business. She dreams of educating her children, continuing her education , and improving their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil wholesale

loans.name: Santusa

texts.en:
Our client is Santusa.  She is part of a communal bank consisting of sixteen neighbors who live in Cusco.  The group is called Santa Rosita de Lima, named after a virgin of Peru.  She is a native of Apurimac but now lives in Cusco.  She is 56 years old and is married with two children and two grandchildren.  

She buys and sells clothing in Tres Cruces, Paucartambo.  She sells approximately 80 soles worth of goods per day, which is approximately $28.  With this loan, she will buy more clothing from wholesale vendors in the area.

Santusa appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell

loans.name: Gran Fortaleza De San Jeronimo Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal; “LA FORTALEZA DE SAN JERONIMO”; Nuestros socios son un grupo muy alegre y muy bien organizado, ellos son 14 socios, se ausentó una de las socias, la Sra Mery F., debido a que se fracturó la mano hace 3 días atrás; pero en su representación está la hermana de la socia, ellos se reúnen en el distrito de Huanchac en el local de la institución.

Nuestros socios alternan sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista en todas sus formas, un socio vende  ceviche (plato típico de Perú a base de pescado y limón), otras dos socias atienden un restaurante de platos típicos, otro socio es albañil, otro es mecánico, otras socias venden ropa, otras trabajan en un hospedaje, haciendo la limpieza general, otro socio está en la venta de auto partes, otro maestro de obras, otras socias venden en sus carretas pollipapas y salchipapas, otras venden comidas en general y venta de papa en el mercado. Todos nuestros socios requieren el préstamo para poder de este modo reinvertir en sus diferentes negocios, haciéndolos prosperar y crecer más.

Nuestros socios agradecen y valoran el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus diferentes deudas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
This group belongs to the communal bank "La Fortaleza de San Jeronimo." The group is comprised of 14 members who are happy and very well organized. One of the members, Senora Mery F., is absent, due to the fact that she injured her hand three days prior, but pictured in her place is her sister. This group meets in the Huanchac distract where the bank is located. These members alternate their activities in the home with retail trade in all its forms: one member sells ceviche (a typical dish of Peru made with fish and lemon), other members serve in a restaurant that sells typical Peruvian dishes, another member is a bricklayer, another is a mechanic, other members sell clothing, others work in a boardinghouse doing general cleaning, another sells auto parts, another is a master builder, other members sell pollipapas y salchipapas (typical Peruvian meals of chicken or sausage served with fried potatoes) on the streets, others sell meals in general and sell potatoes in the market. All of the members need a loan to reinvest in their businesses, so as to make them prosper and grow. These members appreciate and value the loan granted through these means, and they are committed to making the payments on their various debts on time.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to reinvest in their various businesses

loans.name: María

texts.es: María es una socia trabajadora, vive en el kilómetro 17 de la carretera Federico Basadre, región de Ucayali, tiene 63 años, es madre de dos hijos, mayores de edad, ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en general al por menor, este negocio lo tiene instalado en su casa, ella trabaja junto a una de sus hijas. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Las Ucayalinas”  desde hace seis años. El primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles, que invirtió en la compra de gaseosas, ahora María necesita un crédito de 1000 soles que será utilizado, una parte para ampliar su bodega (infraestructura) y otra parte para comprar productos para la misma (arroz, azúcar, fideos, detergente, etc.). La meta de María es incrementar sus productos y mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
María is one of our hardworking members. She lives at Km 17 of the Federico Basadre Highway in the region of Ucayali. She is 63 years old and the mother of two adult children. She sells groceries out of her home and is assisted by one of her daughters.

María joined the Communal Bank “Las Ucayalinas” six years ago. Her first loan of 300 soles was used to purchase sodas. She is now requesting a loan of 1000 soles and will use part of it to expand the infrastructure of her store. With the remaining amount, she will buy her usual products (rice, sugar, noodles, detergent, etc.). María’s goal is to increase her inventory and improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand her store & purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Andres

texts.es:
el so Andres H. C. se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, su negocio opera bajo el nombre de pulpería "San Antonio" rubro que mas resalta en nuestra sociedad, el es soltero pero le brinda el estudio y todos los gastos a sus dos hermanas,  cubre a un 100% los gastos de la alimentación para sus dos hemananas y su madre, ya que su padre fallecio y él era el unico hijo varon y se quedo viviendo en el mismo terreno de su padre pero en casa diferente, ya que el posee su propia vivienda.
Andres nos comento que se siente muy feliz por estar ayudando a sus hermanas, lo que el desea es que ellas sean unas buenas profesionales, quiere graduarlas de la universidad para que se puedan defender en la vida cuando esten grandes.
Andres solicita el credito para poder abastecer su negocio ya que las exigencias de sus clientes son muchas y a veces se le termina el producto.
texts.en:
Andres H. C. sells popular consumer items for a living. His business is called pulpería (a small store located in one’s home) "San Antonio" which is a resonate name in our society. He is single, but takes care of his sisters’ education and all of their expenses. He covers 100% of his sisters’ and mothers’ expenses and food since his father died leaving him the only son. He lives on his father’s land, but in his own home. Andres says that he is very happy to be able to help his sisters. He wants them to be professionals and to graduate from college so they are able to take care of themselves when they grow up. Andres is asking for a loan to supply his business since his customers order a lot which causes him to run out of his product.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soap to wash clothes, lard, oil, soft drinks, donuts, beans, tortillas, bread , TP, coffee, pasta, cereal, salsa, eggs, corn meal, flour, cheese, and butter

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
Cecilia es una socia colaboradora y dinámica, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 41 años, es madre de tres hijos, menores de edad. Ella se dedica a la venta de golosinas y bebidas, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo que se desempeña como docente de educación. Cecilia forma parte del Banco Comunal “Ricardo Palma” desde hace cinco años. El primer crédito que recibió fue para comprar gaseosas para vender.
Ahora ella requiere un crédito de 1000 soles, que será utilizado para comprar golosinas al por mayor. La meta de Cecilia es tener un negocio bien surtido de abarrotes en general.
texts.en:
Cecilia is a collaborative and dynamic member. She lives in the city of Pucallpa in the Ucayali region. She is 41 years old and the mother of three young children. Cecilia sells candy and beverages and has the support of her husband, who has a teaching position. Cecilia has been part of the “Ricardo Palma” communal bank for the past five years. The first loan that she received was to purchase sodas to sell.

Now Cecilia needs a loan of 1000 PEN, which she will use to purchase wholesale candy. Cecilia’s goal is to have a well-assorted general grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wholesale candy

loans.name: Children Mother Group

texts.en:
'Children Mother' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Korto M., 37 years old, married with 3 children aged 7-16 years old; the oldest child is in 7th grade. Korpo is an illiterate due to poverty. She and her family live in Ziggida Town, a small town close to Zorzor, a district in Lofa county, northern Liberia.

Korto’s business is the sale of general goods like fresh eggs, tomato paste, bathing soap, etc. She buys general goods wholesale and sells retail on a table to residents of Ziggida town. She has been running this business for only one year and is hoping to expand to a bigger table.

Korto sells quality goods in order encourage customers to continue buying from her. She used to sell vegetables but later realized that general goods are more profitable than vegetables, so took all the funds she had saved up while selling vegetables and started her general goods business.

She needs this loan in order to purchase more general goods wholesale to improve business. Korto dreams of giving her children a better education and changing their living standard.

loans.use: to purchase more general goods wholesale to improve business

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas L. is thirty-nine years old. He was born in a village call Magborie, near Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. Thomas is married to a businesswoman and they have seven children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Thomas is also a farmer. He wants a loan of SLL 1,000,000 to invest in his farm. He will use the loan to pay laborers and to buy seeds.

loans.use: To buy seeds and pay for labor

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Our client is Mario.  He is part of a communal bank consisting of sixteen neighbors who live in Cusco.  The group is called Santa Rosita de Lima, named after a virgin of Peru.  He is a native of Cusco and now lives in Santiago, Cusco.  He is 61 years old and is married with two children who are in college.

He buys all types of music CDs from distributors and sells them in Juliaca, Puno and Arequipa. He sells about 30-50 soles worth of goods per day, which is approximately $10-18 per day.  With this loan, he will buy more CDs to sell.

Mario appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy CDs to sell

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
Maribel es una persona perseverante y activa que lucha por sus ideales, vive en el caserío Señor de los Milagros que se encuentra ubicado en el kilometro 21 carretera de Torna vista en el distrito de Campo Verde, región de Ucayali, tiene 30 años y es madre de tres hijos (menores de edad), ella se dedica a la crianza de pollos, para ello cuenta con un galpón (casa para aves) para criar estas aves, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo que se dedica a la agricultura. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mi Señor de los Milagros” desde hace un año, el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles que invirtió en golosinas para vender en la vereda de su casa (ambulante).
Actualemnte Maribel necesita un préstamo de 1000 que será utilizado para invertir una parte en alimento balanceado para pollos que posteriormente venderá en el mercado de su localidad y otra parte invertirá en la compra de insumos para la preparación de juanes (arroz envuelto en hojas)y tallarines que venderá por las noches en su casa. La meta de Maribel es tener un restaurante bien implementado.
texts.en:
Maribel is a perseverant and active person that fights for her ideals. She lives in the Señor de los Milagros hamlet, located at kilometer 21 of the Torna highway in the district of Campo Verde in the Ucayali region. She is 30 years old and is the mother of three young children. She is involved in the raising of chickens and has a shed (or coop) to raise these birds. Maribel also has the support of her husband who is involved in agriculture.

She has been a member of the “Mi Señor de los Milagros” communal bank for the past year. The first loan that she received was for 300 PEN, which she invested in the purchase of candy to sell on her house’s sidewalk.

Maribel currently needs a loan of 1000 PEN, which she will use to invest partly in balanced feed for the chickens that used to be sold in her local market, and she will invest the other portion in the supplies to make “juanes” (rice wrapped in leaves) and noodles that she will sell at night in her house. Maribel’s goal is to have a well set up restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of chicken feed and to invest in the preparation of her regional dishes

loans.name: Nora

texts.es: Nora es una socia colaboradora y dinámica, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa, región de Ucayali, tiene 39 años, es madre de tres hijos menores de edad, ella se dedica al alquiler de motocarro (transporte), negocio que comparte con su esposo. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Rumbo al Éxito” desde hace dos años. Su primer crédito fue de 300 soles, que fue utilizado para la compra de lubricantes de motos para vender posteriormente, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 1200 soles, que utilizará para comprar un motocarro de segunda mano y ponerlo en alquiler. La meta de Nora es poder construir cuartos para alquilar.
texts.en:
Nora is a collaborative and dynamic member. She lives in the city of Pucallpa in the Ucayali region. She is 39 years old, and is the mother of three young children. She is involved in “motocarro” (three wheeled motorized vehicle) rental, a business that she shares with her husband.

She has been a part of the “Rumbo al Éxito” (Bound for Success) communal bank for the past two years. Her first loan was for 300 PEN, which she used for the purchase of “motocarro” lubricants to sell.

Now, Nora needs a loan of 1200 PEN, which she will use to purchase a second-hand “motocarro” and put it up for rental.

Nora’s goal is to be able to build rooms to rent.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a second-hand "motocarro"

loans.name: Udiedi 1,2,3 Group

texts.en:
Elena lives in Santo Domingo, the crowded capital of the Dominican Republic, where traffic jams and intense heat are more reliable than electricity and running water. She is the group coordinator of her group "Udiedi" and is wanting to take out her second loan through Esperanza International.

Elena will be using this loan to buy a pack of tennis shoes to sell to her customers. Selling tennis shoes results in a larger profit than selling clothing, but requires more initial capital to buy them, so she is very thankful for this loan. She is thankful to Esperanza for having low and manageable repayments which has allowed her to reinvest more money into her business. She looks forward to taking out more loans in the future to help her business grow and to support her house and family financially. Thank you for your help!

loans.use: Shoes

loans.name: Rosaura

texts.es: Rosaura es una socia trabajadora y dinámica, vive en la ciudad D. Pucallpa región D. Ucayali, tiene 60 años, madre D. seis hijos mayores D. edad. Rosaura se dedica a la venta D. prendas D. vestir, actividad que desarrolla en su casa, cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo, él es jubilado (cesado,ya no trabaja) del magisterio. Rosaura forma parte del Banco Comunal “Ricardo Palma” desD. hace cinco años. El primer préstamo que recibió fue D. 300 soles, que utilizó en la compra D. gaseosas, ahora ella necesita un préstamo D. 2500 soles, que será utilizado para comprar una vitrina mas, para exhibir su mercadería y también para comprar prendas D. vestir. La meta D. Rosaura es  tener una tienda D. artículos D. regalos para toda ocasión.
texts.en:
Rosaura is a hard-working and dynamic woman. She lives in the city of Pucallpa, in the region of Ucayali, Peru, and is a 60-year-old mother of six, all of whom are grown up. She makes a living selling clothes, an activity she carries out from her home. She counts on the support of her husband, who is a retired teacher. She has been a part of the Ricardo Palmo Community Bank for the past five years. Her first loan was for 300 soles, and she used it to purchase soft drinks to sell. Currently she is requesting a loan of 2500 soles (approximately $875), which she plans to use to purchase a display case to show off her merchandise and to also purchase more clothing to sell. Rosaura's goal is to have a store selling gifts for all occasions.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing and a display case to show offer her merchandise

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.es:
Eufemia es una socia colaboradora y muy trabajadora, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 53 años y es madre de tres hijos todos mayores de edad,  Eufemia se dedica a la venta de pescados y mariscos, esta actividad la realiza en un mercado de la zonas, ella trae los mariscos de la ciudad de Lima, su esposo le apoya siempre, él se dedica a la pesca. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres trabajadoras” desde hace ocho años, donde es muy querida por las demás socias. El primer crédito que obtuvo fue de 300 soles, que lo invirtió en pescado para vender.
Ahora requiere un crédito de 2800 soles que le permitirá invertir en la compra de mariscos. La meta de Eufemia es  tener una tienda de abarrotes en general y seguir adelante en su negocio.
texts.en:
Eufemia is a hard-working and collaborative member of her community bank. She lives in the city of Pucalpa, region of Ucayali, Peru. She is a 53-year-old mother of three, all of whom are grown up. She makes a living selling fish and seafood at the markets in her area. She brings in the seafood from the city of Lima, and her husband, who is a fisherman, always supports her. Eufemia has been part of the "Mujeres Trabajadoras" ("Working Women") Community Bank for the past eight years and is beloved by the other members. Her first loan was for 300 soles, and she used it to invest in fish to sell. Currently she is requesting a loan of 2800 soles (approximately $975), which she plans to use to invest in the purchase of seafood. Eufemia's goal is to have a general store and make headway with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seafood at wholesale

loans.name: Erika

texts.es:
Erika es una socia dinámica y emprendedora, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa, región  de Ucayali, es madre de dos hijos menores de edad, se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir y zapatos, ella viaja a la ciudad de Lima a traer esta mercadería.  Su esposo de dedica a la venta de motos. 
Erika forma parte del Banco Comunal “Loreto” desde hace tres años, el primer crédito que recibió fue de 300 soles que le permitió invertir en ropa interior para damas, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 3000 soles que será utilizado para comprar prendas de vestir para niños y adultos, ya que ella venderá a crédito esta mercadería. La meta de Erika es tener una tienda de artículos para toda ocasión, y seguir trabajando para progresar.
texts.en:
Erika is a dynamic and enterprising member of her community bank. She lives in the city of Pucallpa, region of Ucayali, Peru. She is the mother of two young children and makes a living selling clothes and shoes. She travels to the city of Lima to bring back this merchandise to sell. Her husband makes a living selling motorcycles. Erika has been part of the "Loreto" Community Bank for the past three years, and her first loan of 300 soles allowed her to purchase women's undergarments to sell. Currently she is requesting a loan of 3,000 soles (approximately $1,050), which she plans to use to purchase clothing for children and adults to sell on credit. Her goal is to have a store selling items for all occasions and to keep progressing with her work.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothes for children and adults

loans.name: Sourou Parfaite

texts.fr: A. Sourou Parfaite vit à Houéyogbé à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Sourou Parfaite vend des céréales (riz, haricot, sorgho, mil, etc.) au grand marché de Porto-Novo. Sourou Parfaite achète ses produits à Ikpinlè, marché des produits vivriers au Bénin. Sourou Parfaite a plusieurs expériences dans ce métier. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a obtenu une fois un crédit dans l'institution, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Sourou Parfaite sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer son activité afin de mieux faire face aux multiples demandes de sa clientèle, et de subvenir aux besoins de sa petite famille.
texts.en:
A. Sourou Parfaite lives in Houéyogbé in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of the Republic of Benin.  She sells grains (rice, beans, sorghum, millet, etc.) at the grand marketplace of Porto-Novo.  She purchases her goods in Ikpinlè, a market for staple foods in Benin.  She has a lot of experience in this trade.  Sourou Parfaite is a former ALIDé client having obtained a loan in this micro-finance institution that she repaid.  She's requesting a second loan from ALIDé for bolstering her business in order to cope better with the multiple orders from her customers and to provide for her small family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains (beans, rice, sorghum, millet, corn)

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel T. is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 from SMT/Kiva lenders. Samuel is forty-two years old and married to a businesswoman. They have five children who are all attending schools, four in secondary schools and one in primary school.

He wants a loan in order to invest in his wife’s food market business.

loans.use: Invest in his wife's food market

loans.name: Natividad

texts.es:
Natividad es una socia emprendedora y colaboradora, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa región de Ucayali, tiene 48 años, tiene un hijo mayor de edad, es madre soltera.
Natividad tiene una bodega de abarrotes que funciona en su casa. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al progreso” desde hace seis años, donde siempre se ha caracterizado por ser una socia muy puntual. El primer crédito que obtuvo en este banco fue de 300 soles que lo utilizó en la compra de golosinas para vender en la vereda de su casa, ahora ella necesita un crédito de 1000 soles que será utilizado para surtir su negocio, comprará arroz, asúcar, fideos, y otros productos. La meta de Natividad es tener una tienda con todo tipo de artículos y seguir trabajando para salir adelante.
texts.en:
Natividad is an enterprising and collaborative member of her community bank. She lives in the city of Pucallpa, region of Ucayali, Peru. She is a 48-year-old single mother, and her son is fully grown. Natividad has a convenience store that she runs out of her home. She has been part of the "Mujeres al progreso" (Women of Progress) Community Bank for the past six years and has always been known for being a very punctual member. Her first loan from the community bank was for 300 soles, and she used it to purchase snacks to sell on the sidewalk at her house. Currently she is requesting a loan of 1,000 soles (approximately $350), which she plans to use to stock her business by purchasing rice, sugar, noodles and other products. Natividad's goal is to have a store selling all kinds of items and to keep working to make headway.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her store by purchasing rice, sugar, noodles and other items

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: This is Michael K. from northern Sierra Leone. He is forty-five years old and married with five children. Michael’s children are attending primary and secondary schools. His wife is a businesswoman. Michael wants a loan of SLL 1,000,000 to purchase house-building materials.

loans.use: Buy house building materials like cements, iron corrugated zincs, etc

loans.name: Obidanbi Group

texts.en:
Atta is a forty-year-old gentleman. He is married and the father of four children, three boys and a girl, who are currently pursuing education in junior high and primary schools. In his capacity as the main breadwinner of his family, Atta works hard as a trader. He trades in used clothing.

Atta is the leader of "Obidanbi Trust Group" which has seven members, four females and three males. These are all breadwinners for their families. They all have children who are currently in school. They are engaged in the trading of foodstuffs, clothing, cosmetics, groceries, and so on, as the source of livelihood for their homes. However, due to inadequate working capital, they make barely enough income to meet the needs of their households.

Their common dream is to see their businesses grow, which would enable them to improve the living conditions of their families. They believe this loan will help them to inject more capital into their businesses to materialize this dream. Members of this group agree to guarantee for one another as social collateral and to assist one another in repaying the loan on schedule.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Buya

texts.en: This is Buya K. from northern Sierra Leone. Buya is thirty-seven years old and married with six children. His children are all attending school, three in junior secondary school and two in primary school. Buya is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 to purchase house-building materials.

loans.use: Buy house building materials

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel K. is from northern Sierra Leone and is thirty-seven years old. He is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 for the very first time from Kiva Lenders through SMT. With this loan, Samuel will pay school fees and other school related expenses for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en: This is Abdul K., who is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 to buy house equipment/furniture. He is 46, married to a businesswoman, and they have four children, all of whom are attending secondary schools.

loans.use: To buy house equipment and furniture

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia, a 28-year-old married mother of two children currently in the basic school, lives with her family in an old family house. In business for five years, she trades in palm oil, while her husband is a farmer. She buys the palm oil from the local manufacturers in towns and villages and resells to city dwellers.

Palm oil is a local vegetable oil produced from palm fruits that have been cooked, pounded, sieved and boiled for hours. The reddish substance (the oil) is skimmed off and reboiled to expel water content. Lydia desires to use the loan to expand her business by buying the palm oil in bulk in order to sell to more customers and improve her finances.

loans.use: To buy palm oil in bulk.

loans.name: Aissatou Taty

texts.fr: Aïssatou est une femme de 53 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants qui sont tous à l'école. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de BOUCOTTE CENTRE depuis 4 ans et y a bénéficié de 8 prêts qu'elle a remboursés sans difficulté. Elle achète du maïs et le transforme en couscous pour le vendre. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Aïssatou, 53, is married and the mother of 4 children who are all enrolled in school. She has been a member of the Village Bank of BOUCOTTE CENTRE for 4 years and has received 8 loans which she has repaid without difficulty. She buys maize and transforms it into couscous to sell. Her profit permits her to participate in the improvement of living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolster her business

loans.name: Muhamed

texts.en: This is Muhamed S.. He is 49 years old, married to a businesswoman, and they have five children together, all of whom attend school – three in junior secondary schools and two in primary schools. Muhamed is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders for the first time to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Bernall

texts.en: Bernall C. A. is 47 years old and is married with six children who are his first priority. They are ages 26, 24, 24, 20, 17, and 5 respectively, and three of them still live at home. He is requesting a loan so that he can buy fertilizer and pay for farm help. He has his own farm where he grows coffee and tends cattle with the help of his family. This loan will allow him to continue growing coffee without having to sell off his cattle assets to pay for the fertilizers needed. This is his first loan with Fudecosur, and he is excited to have a village bank in his community, as he never had other sources of credit available to him. He hopes that his children remain healthy and receive the education they deserve.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pay for farm help

loans.name: Josiane

texts.fr: A. Josiane est née le 15 Janvier 1969 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Josiane habite au quartier Agbokou  à Porto-Novo depuis vingt sept ans. Mariée à MEGBLETO Albert, Josiane est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par les deux conjoints. Josiane est une couturière qui vend également des tissus et du charbon de bois. Josiane s’approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin ; elle a une boutique à Agbokou. Josiane a déjà vingt ans d’expérience dans ce métier. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Josiane sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé
texts.en:
Josiane A. was born January 15, 1969 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Josiane has lived in Porto-Novo's Agbokou neighborhood for seven years. Married to Albert Megbleto, Josiane is the mother of three children who are all in school. The family's expenses are paid by both spouses. Josiane is a dressmaker who also sells fabric and wood coal. Josiane gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin; she has a store in Agbokou. Josiane already has twenty years of experience in this trade. She is a former client of Alidé who has already taken two loans from Alidé, loans that she has repayed well. Josiane is requesting a third loan from Alidé to increase her working capital and to better satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bags of wood coal and pieces of fabric

loans.name: Estrellas Group

texts.es:
la sra. MIRNA YOLANDA L. D. su principal actividad es la pulpería, misma que opera bajo el nombre de Pulpería "ALEXANDER" ella vive en unión libre y es madre de 4 hijos los cuales estan en edades de 10 años a 5 años, dos de ellos estan cursando la primaria y uno en preparatoria.
su compañero de hogar es agricultor, Siembra de granos básicos y su especialidad es la siembra de maíz y frijoles.- Mirna establecio este negocio ya que solo se dedicaba al cuidado de sus hijos y la situación economica para ellos no era tan favorable ya que su compañero de hogar era el responsable en un 100% con los gastos del hogar.- ahora con su negocio la situación a mejorado en gran manera ya que ella aporta para comida y cubre algunos gastos dentro del hogar en lo poco que  puede.
el sr. SANTOS ISIDRO V. se dedica a la venta y compra de cerdos en pie tambien se dedica a la agricultura siembra de granos básicos (maíz y frijoles).
don santos sale a comprar los cerdos fuera de la aldea de Sta. Maria, y los trae en manada hasta el lugar donde el vive, y a los dos dias llega un comprador a quien les vende los animales.
el vive en union libre y no tienen hijos, y solo depende de ellos un hermano de su 
compañera de hogar por motivos de enfermedad vive con ellos.
Don santos, es una persona bien reconocida en la aldea de Sta. Maria, por el tipo de negocio que tiene ademas es una persona con mas de 30 años de residir en esta aldea.
el sr. JOSE FERMIN B. P. se dedica al comercio, su principal actividad es la venta de plasticos, sandalias de hule, frutas y verduras; anteriormente el vivia en la capital
de este país, pero por problemas maritales, se separo de su esposa y se vino a vivir a la 
tierra de donde es él, haciendose responsable de la crianza de 2 de sus tres hijos.
don josé, es una persona que lucha solo para poder educar a sus hijos mismos que en estos
momentos estan cursando la educacion primaria.
el Sr. B., compra los productos plasticos y sandalias en la capital, y luego sale a vender a comunidades y zonas cafetaleras cercanas a Sta. María. posee un carro y cuado sale a vender a las zonas cafetaleras el compra platanos y bananos y se va venderlos a la capital de donde saca mejores ganacias ya que hace 2 negocios en un solo viaje.
todos ellos necesitan el credito para poder salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mirna Yolanda L. D. has a pulpería (a small general store in her home) called "ALEXANDER". She lives with her partner and is the mother of 4 children ages 10 to 5 years old, two of whom are in elementary school and one who is in middle school. Her companion is a farmer who plants basic grains. His specialty is growing corn and beans. Mirna established this business on her own because she was only taking care of children and their economic situation was not very good since her partner was 100 percent responsible for the household expenses.
